reviewText:
The stitching around the leather holding the IWB clip was very poor on one side as it was not tacked properly. I don't know if the stitching would continue to pull out if it was used as it is since the belt goes across it and presses against it, but the quality sure suffers with such poor stitching.  The rest of the holster appears to be stitched okay.  Apparently, a Quality Control issue.  Someone is not checking the sewing process closely.

I bought this for a S&W Model 659 9mm.  There is no way the gun will fit into this holster without destroying the holster.  I can get the barrel in up to just past the trigger guard and it will go no farther.  I also tried my Glock 29 (Glock calls it a subcompact) and it would not fit either.  The body of the Glock is wider than the S&W and I could not even get the trigger guard started into the holster.  How anyone determined this holster was suitable for a large frame semi-auto is beyond me.  Both of these pistols have large, square trigger guards.  Now I am going to have to be out postage to return this improperly advertised and defective piece of merchandise to Holster World.

The distance across the holster at the top is about 4 3/4 inches.  Inside the stitching it is 3 7/8 inches.  At the bottom it is about 3 7/8 inches.  Inside the stitching it is 3 1/4 inches.  The height is 2 7/8 inches.  This is not suitable for a large frame pistol.

8/13/2014  Addendum:  Decided that I did not want to be out money to send this holster back, so bought a subcompact that I had been wanting, a Kahr CM9.  This gun fits this holster quite well.  The leather on this holster is fairly thick and so adds a bit of bulk.  Again, I do not see how this holster is meant for larger weapons.  The CM9 fits pretty good, but any gun larger than it would cause problems as far as I can tell.
summary: Holster not suitable for large frame semi-autos and it has defective stitching.  Poor QC.

reviewText:
When it arrived the rim was bent in multiple places, so much so that I had to take it to a bike shop instead of truing the wheel myself.  The brakes were also so far out of adjustment that I had to have the bike shop fix them as well.

The pros are that the bike is light and seems to perform well so far.  The tire grade seems average at best with max pressure being only about 50 psi (all of my other bike tires have been thicker and had max pressures around 65 psi). The gear system seems to respond well, and the light weight is useful for transporting as well as riding.

Update:  I haven't been able to ride this bike since spring 2015 since the pedal arm literally stripped out of the frame half way through a bike ride.  The only way to fix it is to pay someone to weld it on.  Also it seems that the rim gets bent if you hit anything.  The handle bar grips are extremely cheap and slide match more easily than they should.

Bike seems to be very cheaply made and better suited for paved trails or roads (if you manage to get one that doesn't have major defects).  Original price unrealistic and only shown to be marked down to attract customers.  This is basically a low end Wal-Mart bike that can fold.
summary: Um.... Ok at first, now trash

I contacted Timex customer service directly, asking only if they had a secret for cleaning the band and was told the following: "Unfortunately there is no substance that will clean a white resin band. However you are more than welcome to purchase a band for your daughters watch. The band is $12.00 and the shipping and handling are included within the US. You are more than welcome to call in at the number provided below and well gladly assist you with the order. Thank you for choosing Timex and have a great day." So in a couple of months, when the band becomes discolored, I can buy another and another...

well, the day after it came i went to sharpen a stick and the Blade got really Loose. i took the cap off and the bolt was secured tight. i left it be for about 2 weeks, finally got around to fixing it, and i tell ya, the handle is the only thing sturdy. while the blade is stainless steel, Heavy use is not a good idea. i first noticed that the blade is really Dull. it doesnt sharpen anything, it didn't even sharpen the stick i mentioned. so i went about sharpening it, and Honed the blade for an entire hour with a File. Yes, A file. Files don't take whole hours for 5 inch Blades. finally i got it decently about as sharp as a kitchen knife.  the blade was so dull at first that i had to apply pressure with the file, and my hand slipped, and right now i got a deep cut on my finger. the knife suprised me that it could cut me cuz i had honed it for an hour before it cut me.when i first pushed straight on the blade before sharpening, nothing happend. still noticing how wobbly the blade was i set about to tightening the bolt to see if that was the problem. i applied the socket wrench with the extender arm and gave one good turn and the blade was secure and not wobbly. finally, i thought the knife was usable, after i sat on the computer for hours choosing the perfect knife, and i thought i had one. one more turn and the damn thing Broke. totally unfixable. so after 20.99, Twenty dollars i could have bought a good knife with, but listend to these false reviews about how lovely it was, so i bought it and payed dearly. as of now i am using the Broken blade for a spear. just to make use of the loss. i kept the compass, which does work. and the fishing line. hopefully no other people out there goes through what i did. Spend wisely, or you could be me.
Get the Teran Tactical +2 instead. You won't regret it.

I bought this cable lock thinking it was a steal of a deal. Nice big numbers for me to see, mounting bracket for convenient storage. Now for the harsh reality. The nice big cable is actually a nice big plastic coating with a skinny wire inside. I had a nice expensive bike had it stolen from the public bike rack in broad daylight. Cops said to never use this type, Thieves know how easy it is to cut the wire with a very small pocket size wire cutter. Might be alright in small town may-berry, but big city thieves actually target bikes with this type of lock. My municipality would have actually replaced my bike if I had the U or D style lock. Wish I had known that prior to loosing an $600 bike after only a month or so.
summary: If it sounds too good to be true, it probably is.

So I've owned this thing for quite a long time.  It's fine for long rides.  It's not good for races.  One handed operation of the zipper is impossible.  Opening the zipper is fine.  It opens great.  If you zip it past the point where the second strap is, you will struggle to zip it up again.  There is too much movement of the bag in that area to give it enough leverage for one handed operation of the zipper.  I spent so much time on my first 70.3 Tri trying to get this bag closed that it will not go back on my bike, ever.  I'm not impressed.

I weigh 140lbs, so the weight wasn't an issue, just in case you are wondering. I inflated it 120psi. Size of the tire was 700x20c.
You can avoid pinch flat snake bites by inflating the tire to certain pressure. If the tire picks up a broken staple, it gets flat but you can patch it. When the tube comes apart, you can't do anything specially if the spare you happen to have has the same defect.

I'll never buy it and I don't recommend this to anybody.

I read all the other reviews and was prepared to be impressed by this cooler only to be bitterly disappointed.  Not with its ability to keep things cold, which it did very well, but with the shoddy construction of the handles.  Loading it into the car on the first day of a 7 day camping trip, the tow handle broke off and then the lifting handle also broke.  By the end of the trip the lifting handle on the other side had also broken.  If you look at the construction, it's very cheaply done and the thickness of the plastic handles and the attachment of the tow handle are very flimsy.  I didn't read all the negative reviews but maybe this has been pointed out already.  I assumed the 100 qt size would have robust handle construction since a full cooler would be very heavy, but I was wrong.  I had to resort to wrapping my arms around it and simply lifting the cooler when I moved it, the wheels were useless without a handle to grab.  Be careful.
summary: Kept food cool but handle construction shoddy and cheap - very disappointed

Nice idea.  Poor execution.  It will not fit a 930 JM Pro without modification.  You will need to grind off at least 1/8th of an inch on the front two screws.  If you don't grind off 1/8th of an inch then the two front screws push down on the barrel tang causing it to visibly raise up in the into the breach.  The result is that the bolt scrapes against the inside of the barrel tang.  Two metal parts rubbing against each other that are not intended to be in contact cannot be a good thing, especially after several rounds and the metal expands.  Sounds like a recipe for disaster, or a jamb in the very least.  I did not expect much for $10, but this piece could be a dangerous addition to the 930 JM Pro.
summary: Will NOT fit a Mossberg 930 JM Pro without modification

I have owned Shimano reels for 30 years and I love them.  I always had the cheaper all black and plastic version for years.  I love fishing and have a pond right in front of our house stocked with fish, dream come true.  Thought it was time to move up and get a real quality reel.  These looked great so I purchased 3 of different sizes.  Some have been better than the others but I have had NOTHING but trouble.  I have had more line messes and tangles than with any other reel I have ever owned.  I love the features but between the constant line messes and the reel not engaging after casting without rocking it back and fourth its not worth it.  I am so incredibly disappointed I can't even put it into words.  It has max ball bearings but it really takes a lot more to reel in than the $12 all plastic black model.  I had one of those for 15 years before it died.  I will be getting more of those and leave these on the shelf.  They are not worth the money and an EXTREME disappointment.

NOTE:  I do use braided line and I am aware that has more issues with tangles but not like what I have experienced with this.
summary: LOOKS GREAT, FEELS GREAT, ...Performs LIKE JUNK!!

Well made but poorly designed, at least in my opinion.  Inaccuracy comes from the fact that this device is hand-held.  No matter how hard you try to hold steady, the pull of your hand cannot be released in the fraction of a second when the trigger breaks.  Your hand continues to pull the gauge to the rear AFTER the trigger breaks so the digital readout is the final force of your pull against the final rear-most position of the trigger.  This problem is most pronounced with a trigger that has over-travel.  To get the best accuracy you have to steady your hand against the stock attempting to minimize this contamination, but still the final readout is an overstated approximation.  I believe this is the source of inaccuracy mentioned by other reviewers.  (The same kind of inaccuracy would occur with a spring-loaded trigger- measuring device, but that is just an aside.  This Lyman device is not spring loaded.)

reviewText:
I just received my Klean Kanteen - probably the 15th I have purchased. I own a couple, and have given many as gifts. But alas, the company has done a bait & switch with the caps. What happened to the stainless steel caps??? They used to come standard. The whole idea was to have the internal part of the screw top to be steel, like the inside of the bottle -  so there's no plastic touching your liquid. The exterior grip on the lid was always plastic - that's fine. But now, you have to buy the original stainless screw cap, as an accessory, that costs more than 1/3 as much as the entire bottle product. This bottle if great, but now go buy the staibless steel cap for $5.45.
Shame on you Klean Kanteen.
summary: What happened to the stainless steel caps?

reviewText: Foolishly I didn't try this out before leaving for a hiking and yoga retreat to Greece. After the first day of hiking I felt that I had a very wet lower tee shirt and top of my hiking pants. I put it down to a four hour 'strong' hike. On the next day it happened again...on checking the lower attachment of the hose to the bladder realized there was a leak. What can you do when you're in a different country and need to make the thing work without leakage? A simple plastic shopping bag (they still have them in Greece) as a receptacle for the leakage. The moral to the story: check out the efficiency of the product before using on a critical trip....my bad!
Save your money and buy a better quality product.  I tried mine and it actually made sighting in take longer and use more ammo. I would have been better off to have sighted in without it.

I don't think I've written a review on this but if I did and weighed it favorably, I'm sorry.  Out of the box the grip on the end of the handle spun roughly, it felt like it was grinding.  I contacted the company (Okumo) and they said they would send me a new one...never happened.  I've used it off and on for the last year and was never really happy with how it felt.  It all felt like it ran rough.  Today I opened it up to clean it and see if I could figure out what made it run so rough and what did I find?  Mild to moderate corrosion over the gears!  This is a SALTWATER reel and yet there is no seal around the edges to keep out water.  The "corrosion" coating they used must be minimal at best.  Every time I come home I wash the reel and then spray it with oil.  I take pretty good care of my equipment so I really didn't expect this.  I've torn apart several reels in the last week or two to do the same thing and NONE of them had corrosion in them.
It's also really hard to get the gears to line up on these reels.  There is a little tiny red mark on the top of one and the bottom of the other to line them up.  The problem is the line isn't exact!  I'm still not sure I have it lined up right though any other setting jams the reel, so I guess it is.  This reel is entirely too complicated for no particularly good reason.  For a reel that is toted as this amazing "crossover" construction, it's actually a piece of crap.
My fault that I let my warranty expire (last month), sure wish I'd checked the guts of this thing a month or two ago.

Don't spend your money on this reel, there are other, better reels for about the same $$, get one of those.
summary: Not smooth, not good for saltwater Trio-40

This air rifle is the biggest piece of turd I've ever purchased.  I did not buy it from Amazon, but it was a newly purchased air rifle.

I can't get it to group better than 2 inches at only 15 yards!
-I've tried 5 different kinds of pellets in all shapes and weights.
-I've cleaned the bore thoroughly.
-I've tightened the barrel pivot screw and all screws holding the stock on.
-I've shimmed underneath the rubber seal in the breach.
-I've put a much better scope on it that is rated for Magnum springer air rifles.
-I've tried many versions of the auxiliary hold that is the most common for springer air rifles.

I've chronographed this Ruger a lot and average velocity is 680fps (marketed as capable of 1,200fps). By comparison, I was chronographing someone's RWS 34 on the same day and it was breaking the sound barrier on some shots and would be occasionally over 1,200fps even though it was rated at only 1,000fps (I think).

I chronographed my son's $30 Daisy 10 pump air rifle also for comparison. It's rated at 770fps shooting BB's. Well shooting the same lead pellets it still gets to 650fps! That's almost as fast as this stupid Ruger!

I'm frustrated... and about to give up on this Ruger. All of the reviews for this thing seem decent. But I can't believe Ruger puts their name on these things.

I'm definitely open to suggestions if anyone has any? I have about 400 rounds through this air rifle to date. Nothing so far has improved the accuracy.
summary: Be warned - WAY slower than advertised and horrible accuracy!

After receiving this product I've come to realize that this, is not a good representation of the Magpul M-LOK product. The #1 and the biggest of issues, one of the Hex Screws had no hex cut out, so it was useless. The second issue, is the fact that the screws do not have the Lock-Tite that Magpul M-LOK OEM comes with, so the product would not work as intended. M-L0K is designed to lock in the hand guard slot and unlock with a simple 1/2 turn or so after it is properly set, this is where the Lock-Tite comes into play.
My other MagPul made M-LOK Pictanny Rails came beveled at the ends which is a nice feature. This Item I received was just square at the ends. The Rail being aluminum was nice, that's about it. If the screws both had a way to use a driver to tighten them, I would probably have just put my own Lock-Tite on them, tighten it down and end of story.  I am waiting Company approval for a return.
I would recommend buying Magpul Brand M-LOK. I would NOT recommend this off brand product.
summary: From my experience stick with Magpul Brand M-LOK if you can

Despite what this is advertised for, it is NOT a MMA or martial arts mat. If you use it for that purpose, you will be highly disappointed as I am. The foam is about 1" thick as advertised. It is non-forgiving, so any type of takedowns or judo throws are completely out of the question unless you feel like breaking bones. For MMA purposes, forget it, you are going to injure yourself badly. For Brazilian Jujitsu, do not even waste your time either. I used this product the day I received the product with one of my jujitsu buddies, afterwards we both vowed to never roll on these mats again and the next day we were all bruised up. I attempted to return them as they are falsely advertised. I was informed that I could send them back if they were in perfect condition, but they wanted to charge me a shipping charge that was a third of the total price of the mats, which was a waste. I wound up storing them in my garage until I can figure out what to do with something as useless as these mats. I will probably just donate them to my friends first grade class for the kids to sit on during storytelling, there aren't much else that these mats would be effective for.

Note: These mats are made in Taiwan...

Mechanical Deficiencies:
My experience while practicing and using these. These broadheads have a tendency to become much harder to open if they get dirty or sandy.  The blades must slide smoothly backwards to deploy correctly.  As you can expect, bowhunting conditions are not perfect and possibility of these getting dirty is real.  Thus, the reliability is not very high in true hunting conditions.  Do you want to take this chance when the opportunity finally comes to arrow your game.

Retention band:
All to often the blades fall loose from the retention rubber band and require you to reset them.  If not set correctly, you can expect failure to deploy correctly.

This is unacceptable by my standards for hunting deer and getting that one chance to shoot a monster buck.  Go with something that is more reliable in hunting conditions. There is enough to think about when that big buck comes out.  The last thing I want to think about is if my broadhead is ready.

These types of reviews get a 1 or 5, especially when taking into account respect of hunting deer.  They either work every time or they don't.  These have failed me.

I don't bike much and this pump isn't exactly the cheapest so I was quite disappointed when after a year the one way valve broke. It was fixed under warranty but not more than half a year later the ABS directly below the pumping mechanism blew a hole. As others have stated the air gets very hot and compromises the integrity of the ABS. That, however, is completely unacceptable.

To mend it, I used a blow torch to close the gap but the fix didn't last long (about 8 times). I've scraped some ABS off other parts of the pump to try to get more ABS on that area but I'm not sure that is going to last, either. I'm sorely disapointed.

Lastly the quick chuck never really worked for my road bike.

It is a pity because I would've loved to love this pump.
summary: Broke within a year, fixed under warranty, then broke again!

This was a relatively expensive purchase for me 24 months ago.  I never ride in the rain by choice but about a month ago I had both my Knogs (white front, black/red rear) out on a ride where it started to rain on the way back during the last 1 mile of a ride.  Well, guess what:  The rear Knog must have gotten exposed because it flaked out and wouldn't switch off or cycle (it was mounted on my rear reflector and must have gotten spray from the rear wheel).  I took out the batteries, sprayed it down with WD-40, and then it operated one more time before getting stuck on solid lights forever.  Sad!  I don't have my receipt from 24 months ago, unfortunately, else I'd send it back.  So, despite the neat design, I conclude that the housing and electronics in production 24 months ago are not sufficiently water-proof/resistant, particularly in the rough world of bicycling.

My Knog looks identical to the one pictured, so I'm assuming it's the same one.  I will not repurchase.
summary: Died a sad water-exposed death far too early for the purchase price

reviewText:
It will cut the tire in 30 minutes. The cut is about 1.5 inches long, looks like made with a knife or a blade, along the tube. The cut is where two ends of the "protector" meet. I am an engineer. I read the reviews about how this product actually causes punctures, but I thought it was from incorrect installation. So, I made sure I followed instructions. Common sense tells me that where two ends of this product meet, they create extra thickness. That extra thickness creates extra pressure on tube, and also there is a sharp edge of the product in exactly same area. All conditions are perfect for creating a cut in your tube.
The manufacturers of such "products" always post reviews about their products: "I bought this for my wife (and / or kids), and my wife has been riding for 10 years without a puncture. My kids love it." All good reviews of this "product" are from manufacturer. I give ZERO stars for this product.
Conclusion: buy a tire that has special puncture-protective layer. There will be pictures of cut-away (slice) of a tire to show that special layer. Example: Schwalbe 700X40 Marathon Plus Tour, W/ Smart Guard
summary: It will cut the tire in 30 minutes

I have a bladder disease: Interstitial Cystitis, therefore I need to urinate a lot, (ie on dog walks in my neighborhood, at the beach, during car rides, you name it). Squatting in public is just not an option anymore. Here are my needs: Discretion is key, comfort, usability and performance are also top priorities. I ordered "Go Girl", "Shewee", "Wiz Freedom" & pStyle. I tried them all right out of the box, without a shower trial. Initially I used my own home bathroom, standing over the toilet with my pants only as far down as discretion would allow. I also tried them with jeans, bicycle shorts and yoga pants. Here are my results:

Shewee- When I used this product I had urine on my clothing. I tried using it 3 times with the same results. Its very bulky and therefore not discrete, The clear tube must be used because the green funnel isn't long enough to exit the urine safely away from the body. It is made of hard plastic, so it will not collapse during use but still needs 2 hands because its so long and narrow you need to hold both ends. It comes with its own caring case, which is a plus. The part of the funnel you hold next to your body is extremely narrow, the funnel itself is so narrow if one was to release a large volume, quickly, I think it would overflow. You also need to wipe afterward because if you try to wipe yourself with it, its just to narrow, plus now you have 2 plastic pieces that are also wet (besides yourself and your clothing). This devise is generally hard to use, indiscrete (dark greenreally?) and bulky both to carry and use. I would give the Shewee a rating of 1 star. I expected more from REI.

Wiz Freedom- Out of the package, first try worked fine. Its flexible and therefore needs both hands to keep it in place and prevent crimping. This devise was not very discrete, anyone seeing you from the side would wonder about this long bright pinkish-purple thing sticking out from between your legs. It doesnt come with a carrying case and I couldn't figure out how on earth I would carry this discreetly in my purse or use it in an emergency. It also  stays wet and theres the issue of self-clean-up, since you are wet after use. At least it doesnt wet your clothing so, I would give this 2 stars.

Go Girl- no leaking on first try, more difficult with elastic clothing due to the flexibility of the product, good discretion, you do need to use both hands to hold it tight to your body and keep it from crimping. I liked that it folded in half- and I could fit it into a small iPhone case on my waist when not in use! I didn't like that there was still moisture in the devise and on my body when I finished, and therefore needed to wipe myself and figure out what to do with the paper. I would give this product 3 stars.

pStyle- Worked great out of the package. Just the right length, the color option of semi-clear lavender makes it discrete as well. Because this devise is made of semi-flexible smooth plastic with rounded edges you can effectively use it to wipe yourself, when you are done. By gently pressing up and away from yourself, you are virtually dry- the last few drops go out the end. If you shake it, the pStle is virtually dry. as well If you want to really get it clean, just use a little water from your water bottle to shoot down the spout. If you buy the caring case you can pop the pStyle in there quickly and easily,  and carry on without any fuss. The case just looks like an eyeglasses case and is totally washable with a Velcro closure. The case also comes in a blue-jean material, it can be hung on a belt loop or on the outside of a bag, purse or backpack with its mini carabiner. Because it is semi-ridged it requires only 1 hand in the middle to hold it in place it won't collapse. It also will not overfill or back-up because it is not a funnel, its more of a half-pipe. This is the only one I use now. I would give the pStle 5 stars, with a BIG thank you to the people who designed and distributed this product.

Long and short I found out by calling the support number that if your motor has the rectangular connector and not the round one at the base the motor it will not work. Needs round connector.  Duh.

Mine was a 2007 motor it just had the wrong connector.  Why they cant say that in the first page of the instructions I don't know.  It was not at all obvious I had the wrong plug for it. It even says all 2007 motors could be converted.  It was not even clear after I had done the entire conversion that was the problem.  The instructions seemed to cover my unit in exact detail as I removed my compass from the old unit and went through the process.  The connectors were the same. The wires the same color etc.

Only the fact it did not work revealed the problem.  When I called in that was the first thing the guy said. Round or rectangular.  Guess they have seen this problem before.  Please put that into the manual next time.
summary: If your motor has the rectangular connector and not the round one at the base this unit will not work. Needs round connector.

I was really excited about this bladder when I received it. It looks great, is easy to open, close, and clean, has an on/off valve, and even has a covered hose! When I started using it though I found several flaws.

The hose is pretty nice. It is easy to scew in and doesn't leak. The on/off valve works well, the bite guard performs admirably, and having a cover is also very convenient. The only real complaint I have is that with the valve and guard/cover it is pretty difficult to get through the hole in the back of packs and through the sleeves down the shoulder straps. Once in place though it is fine.

Being 3L this thing holds a lot of water, which is great. However, I found I could only fill this to about 2L because the main screw on lid leaks. When filled up all the way the lid continuously drips. I examined the gasket and the lid and they both seem fine, so it has to be with how it attaches. The idea of a quarter turn lid is great, but in practice it fails to deliver. I'd take a full screw on lid any day if it means no leaks. I was very unhappy to find that after the hour and a half car ride to the trail head that my pack was wet and my sleeping bag damp. It made for a very uncomfortable first night.

Overall, if you only fill this up to 2L the bladder works well. There are however 2L bladders for cheaper than this, and if I'd wanted to carry 2L I would have purchased one of those. I'll probably be looking for a new bladder soon. This one aimed for above its price range and succeeded in several ways but failed in the most basic sense.

EDIT: I've now taken this out twice, for a total of 3 days on the trail.  It now leaks from the bottom as well as the top. Stopping for the night and finding out your sleeping bag is soaking wet is the worst thing ever. Cannot recommend this product at all. I'll be switching to water bottles from now on
summary: Ok bladder that leaks from main lid if filled all the way...

reviewText: Smaller than advertised by a lot

Please read the update to my initial review !!!

INITIAL REVIEW ...
As others have mentioned, this product is completely useless for Presta valves.  It does not make a good seal and I lose a few LBs of pressure each time a reading is taken.  I wanted to carry it my bike pack for quick readings before taking a ride, it is useless for that.  Even if it worked, it is very "heavy" to carry with you on your bike (in the sense that you would prefer something very light) the heaviness really means solid construction and I think it is well made for shop use, possibly for schrader valves as others suggested.  So I strongly cannot recommend this product for Presta valves.  It is a shame, a simple design change would make this a great tool.

UPDATE TWO WEEKS LATER:
I setup an Amazon return and was ready to send the item back to Amazon.  Before sending it back I went to the Bike Planet because I kept saying to myself, how can this item that appears to be well made simply not work.  Checking the Bike Planet website it actually has a note for this product which says "This Product will not work with removable valve core stems" ...... Oh .... so that explains it .... but wait a minute  ... removable valve stems are so common .....

Thinking about it more, now I started to get mad .... "They clearly say on their website that this will not work with some presta valves so now they need to update the Amazon site to avoid customer frustration.  So now ready to "give them a piece of my mind" I wait until Monday morning and call Bike Planet.  I speak to a young lady in customer service and tell her what happened .... she says "Oh, we made a design change and we have a new adapter which will work with all Presta Valves, I will send it to you in the mail"  WHAT did you say??

So three days later, I receive the newly designed nose piece and it works great.  Luckily I called Bike Planet because I ended up with a really nice gauge.  Problem solved.

So here is what you need to know.

1.  The item as shown in the photo has a really short nose piece and will not work with Presta valves with a removable core.
2.  As of August 2016, Bike Planet made a design change and the item DOES work for Presta Valves with removable cores.
2.  Bike Planet does not advertise that yet on their website (8/14/2016).  They actually say it won't work.
3.  Which version will you get from the various sellers on Amazon... who knows?  Ask the seller before you buy.
4.  Worst case, if you get the wrong nose from your amazon seller, Bike Planet will send you the correct piece

I hope this helps
summary: IF YOU ONLY READ ONE REVIEW ... READ THIS ONE !!!

Please be aware that the product line from Ultimate Survival Technologies from WA was recently sold to Revere Supply Company in FL. One of the first things they appear to have done is to start modifying perfectly good products in order to save a buck. This is clearly evident with the StrikeForce firestarter. While the blister pack outline shows how big the firesteel used to be, it has now been shortened a half-inch or more. I own the older product and have compared it to the newer offering in the store, where the old stock was hanging with the new stock. Also, in some cases they used to include a cube of their WetFire tinder for practice -- now they no longer do so. Between this and Revere Supply's handling of customer service, I cannot in good faith recommend this newer version of the product.

reviewText: The description ..." fits the Taurus Judge 6 1/2"... is accurate only to a point... As flimsy as this holster is, it would "fit" about anything from a pistol to a drill... It offers very little protection to the gun. Holster is very lightweight and flimsy... The metal clip easily slips out of the sewn in slot. The straps flat did not work with one hand... the snap was so tight, it would literally almost tear the velcro strip before it would release and the material of the one strap was very thin and flimsy. I was in a bind and had to make this thing work so I took the straps off one of my Uncle Mike's holsters for another pistol and used them... The Judge is a heavy revolver and this holster is so soft and flimsy, it does not hold it well at all. After 2 trips afield the barrel of my gun now sticks out the bottom of the holster enough to expose the fiber optic front sight... and that's what I most wanted to protect. If the product was returnable, I would do so.
Too bulky and overall not as functional as I hoped.

I have several of these shirts in long sleeve and short and love them. They are a thin cotton material and really airy.  They're good for everyday use when you're not trying to dress up but be comfortable in whatever you're doing. The pink color is not bold, but a muted type color which is very nice and doesn't scream summer. The sizes are accurate. I wear a large in all shirts and no exception with these bonehead shirts. And since these are made of cotton they do wrinkle, which don't bother me at all.

UPDATE:  I was so excited about the pinkish color one and the first time I wore it I received several compliments while out shopping.  That's the good.  But, the UGLY is the fact on both sleeves around the seams of the arms back and front there are white splotches where it looks like the color was completely removed.  I noticed it after coming home from being out all day.  It was new when I wore it and it hadn't even been washed yet.  After washing it the white spots are still there.  I was only shopping, not hiking or doing any strenuous work. I think its weird as some of the spots or on the top of the sleeve, not a place perspiration would normally be a problem (if thats what the problem is). I'm afraid this pink shirt I purchased will ultimately completely fade and I'll have to throw it out.  I'm so dissapointed :(  I'm changing my rating from 5 stars to 4 stars.  I would even reduce it more, but I purchased several of these shirts and none of the others have faded at all.  I own the white, beige, orange, blue and the pink one. I'm contacting Columbia to see if they've received any complaints about the specific pink color one.  Maybe its the dye they used?  Other than this issues, I believe these shirts are outstanding. So, be aware if you purchase the pink one.
UPDATE 2/26/2016 - Both the Pink Orchid color and the Peach color have white blotches. The blue one hasn't turned white yet.  I'm placing them in the mail this coming week. Columbia provided me with claim numbers.  I now own at least 25 Columbia shirts and these were the only ones I've ever had issued so with. Hope, your purchase isn't similar.  I have changed my rating to 2 stars from 5.
summary: Fits as expected (UPDATE on fading issue)

I really, really had high hopes for these.  I am an indoor target shooter at a range that has 14 lanes.  I have owned just about every form of ear pro out there.  I am also a drummer, and have custom molded in-ear monitors that also block external loudness.  I tried 3 different tips on these Etymotics, and each one let me down.  Also, the left earpiece whistled on and off endlessly the 2 days I used these plugs.  These let FAR TOO MUCH external sound into my ears, and I know and understand what a proper seal for earplugs feels like.  I know I had these in correctly, and effectively.  The "Blast Protection" they mention on the product is fine if you are shooting .22LR ammo.  Shooting 9mm and .45acp is plain-old out of the question if you value your hearing.  The plugs do do a good job of boosting low-volume sounds, but the loud bursts are not muted nearly enough.  I don't get how these can be sold as Shooter's Plugs.

Edited after about a month of use: sadly my original hopes of having found some wonderful inexpensive iron sights turned out to be false.

Not only do they not hold zero, but the reason why is obvious if you wiggle the top of the rear sight. The rear sight has a play of at least 1mm! If you have any intention or shooting precisely with these beyond point blank, this is obviously totally unacceptable. I give it two stars rather than one because for purely backup sights, maybe some people would find this okay. Personally, I see very little reason to have sights at all if they're so inaccurate.
summary: Floppy plastic parts; do not hold zero

reviewText:
I tried the Fuel Belt, Nathan Belt, and Amphipod in a store before choosing the Amphipod belt.

The Nathan Belt had the most comfortable elastic band, and the bottles were easy to remove and place onto the belt. However, I didn't like the placement of the bottles as the front bottles interferred with my arm swing (on the 4-bottle belt). Even if you remove the front two bottles, the cup holster still got in my way. With the 2-bottle belt, it rode comfortably on my backside, but I couldn't reach the pouch to grab jelly bellies and goo on the run. With the bottles in front, I ran into the problem of my arms swinging into the bottles again.

The Fuel Belt was comfy, but not as comfy as the Nathan. Had the same problem as the Nathan in terms of arms hitting the bottles and not being able to access the pouch when it's situated on my back. Additional disadvantage of the Fuel Belt is that it takes two hands to place the bottles back in the holster. Also, I seem to fall between sizes where the small was too small and the medium too large.

I ended up purchasing the Amphipod b/c of its flexibility. I'm 5'3", 110 lb.  Although it took a few tries to figure out how to configure the belt, I finally got it so that the bottles would stay out of the way and I could still reach the pouch to grab my jelly bellies on the run. I wish I could run with the belt on my hips, but it's much more comfortable on my waist. With it on my hips, even though I tightened it completely, it had a tendency of riding up b/c of the movement of my legs or when removing the bottles. Additionally, you could feel the weight of the bottles bouncing more with the belt around my hips (especially in the rear!). Around my waist, the rear bottles sat comfortably on the small of my back (sideways to minimize sloshing). I found that the belt stayed in place as long as I wore it just tight enough to wrap comfortably around my waist. It didn't move much b/c it naturally sat in the curve of my waist (and I don't have curves!), so I didn't feel constricted at all. It takes a little getting used to, but it's not uncomfortable at all.

Some people mentioned that it was hard to snap the bottles in and out.  I found this to be extremely convenient since you can access the bottles with just one hand, allowing your other arm to maintain its swing. It takes a little practice to get the feel for it, but it was very easy to remove and replace the bottles in the holster. If you're unsure, just jiggle the bottle slightly to make sure it's locked in place. Again, you can do this all with one hand, unlike with the Fuel Belt.  Overall I'm happy with my purchase. I wish the belt part was as comfortable as the Nathan belt, but I need the adjustability factor due to my petite frame.  Hope this helps!
summary: Interferes w/ arm swing & pouch not accessible while running

I bought two of these, one for each of my bikes. As many reviewers have stated, the light is amazingly bright for such a small, inexpensive unit. Bell really got that part right. However, the physical construction is extremely poor.

The release tabs on both units quickly broke. One the first one, I accidentally knocked the light against a pole while locking up and it snapped the tab off. However, there was enough of the catch mechanism left on on the housing that I was able to continue using the light by holding it in place with a strong rubber band. The release tab lasted about 4 months. On the second unit, the housing was so loose that the light just slid off every single time I picked up my bike with the front lower angled downward. Seriously, it was like a wet kid going down a water slide. No resistance whatsoever. As I wiggled the release tab to see if it would catch on to the light unit, it snapped off in my hand like a pretzel. This happened on the first day of use.

There was another major flaw that common to both units I received: Every time I went over a bump in the road, the light would switch off. Trying to replicate the problem, I held the light in the palm of my hand and firmly tapped it with my other hand. Both lights would switch off every time I did this. Pretty terrible, definitely not what you want while riding around NYC.

In my opinion, the Dawn Patrol headlight is perfect for a quick evening ride around the cul de sac. For anyone thinking to use this for long commutes on varied urban terrain, or for off-road riding, I would strongly recommend against getting this light. It is simply too poorly constructed to function properly on anything but the smoothest rides.
summary: Inexpensive and bright, but with fatal flaws

First off, this bike was missing a couple brake pads right out of the box.  Luckily I have a lot of bike parts laying around so I could scavenge what I needed to complete it.  Second, this bike is pretty heavy, easily as heavy if not heavier than my full-sized 29er mountain bike.  The little "derailleur protector" piece broke off right away (cheap pot metal).  Overall it's a cheap bike made of cheap materials and components.  If you need a kids bike and don't want to spend a lot of money on something they'll grow out of in a year, then this isn't too bad.  But, if you want a bike that will last, this is not that bike.  But again, if your kid's going to out grow this bike in a year, then it's a decent purchase, just don't expect it to be there for a hand-me-down to a younger sibling.  (Disclaimer, my mother-in-law bought this bike for our oldest boy from Amazon, but I'm the one who put it together and tries to keep it running on a regular basis...I was not consulted before this purchase, but we appreciate her generosity none the less.)
summary: Cheap bike, cheap materials, cheap components

I guess I'm the only one who doesn't like it. The problem is that they are cords, after all. When you pull on it there is only resistance at the end of the motion. If you decide to use a heavier cord for whichever exercise you're doing, then you won't be able to pull it far enough. Basically, it's a lose-lose situation. Too light = pull too easily but can go all the way with the effort in the end. Too heavy = you can pull at the beginning but not really at the end. This makes for a "half" pull on every pull, if you know what I mean.

Then when this dawns on you, you realized you just spent $130 on a bunch of rubber tubes and straps. I admit that I mostly bought them so I can do a tricep pull down, because I really loved the machine in the gym. Don't bother. There is that "half-pull" problem and on top of that it feels nothing like the one in the gym. Also, with cords, it feels like most of the effort is used just to balance the cord as you move it and the exercise itself isn't even about your muscle anymore.

Also, I should have trusted my instincts. In their training vids, they have the cords attached to a steel door. I don't know about you but my normal door, which isn't weak, is already starting to seem like it will degrade if I continue to use my cords on it (even if I use the hinge side). It's definitely not going to fly long term. I also read other reviews in the lower priced packages where people wrote that the smaller cords (including the red one) have snapped while they used it. So as I use the cords, that fact is always looming over my head. It's rubber, it will weaken over time, no matter what. I purposely wear my glasses when I use them so it doesn't take out my eye. This also shows that the product will definitely not last (bodylastics does have a solution to this though, apparently after 2 months after purchasing you can still replace cords for a lower price). But to me, it's just not worth the trouble.

I gave this product 2 stars because it is exactly what it is - so it deserves 1 star above the lowest possible rating. You get what you get in the picture. But I gotta say, don't be fooled by their videos with the trainers/actors using it and really "selling" it. In reality it's just nowhere near as fantastic at all and I am 100% certain that those trainers do not use them on a regular day. And again, it's $130 for rubber tubes and velcro straps. Even though they're the best rubber tubes on the market... they're still rubber tubes. Again, there is nothing wrong (so far) with the product. This is just my personal opinion.

I am by no means a disgruntled customer and I am not going to return the product because I believe it was exactly what I bought (there are no defects). But do take my review as a warning. Right now, my bag is sitting by itself, unused. I may give it a few more tries for the novelty fun of it, and to make the best of the $130 I spent, but mark my words, it will eventually go down in time as "junk."

reviewText: This mount looks nice, but performance was not satisfactory. Even with the screws all jacked down tight, the mount still walks down the barrel with every shot of full power 12 gauge and the flashlight would be pulled forward. Loctite (blue) and the included spacer sheet helped alleviate the loose light (Surefire G2X Tactical) but even with Loctite the mount itself still slowly crept down my barrel. Farmer tight and with plenty of blue Loctite, it still happens. Plus the includes clear cushion pads to protect the barrel do a poor job of it. My barrel and mag tube have scratches from the shifting mount even with the pads installed exactly per the instructions. Not only that, but the clear pads are coming loose and one is sticking out from behind the mount. For the money this mount blows and is not worth it. I believe half if not more of the people on here haven't even fired their shotgun with full power loads to see what this mount really is like. I will be seeking a different mount for my other defensive shotguns.

I'm giving this product a 1 star review for one simple reason...the advertised dimensions are pretty far from the ACTUAL dimensions.  When you buy something on-line these sort of details are important.

First off the dimensions listed here are for the outside of the case.  I had a suspicion that was the case...no pun intended.  Keep in mind this case is all sorts of funky bevels and recesses so you loose a lot of actual internal space because of this sci-fi design.

However, even the internal dimensions that Plano lists on their literature, like the hand tag that came attached to this case (which is curiously absent from here) are, shall we say...wishful thinking.  They claim internally it's 13" x 9.5" x 2.5".  Well the 2.5" is close at least.

Here are the actual useful dimensions.  Distance in the center lengthwise between padlock holes; 11.5".  12.75" otherwise.  Distance in the center widthwise where the handle is; 7.125".  Distance widthwise between latches; 8.25".  The rest of the space widthwise is wasted space.  You might, MIGHT be able to jam a thin 9" cleaning rod in there in that small space between the latches and the handle hole.

I bought this case for a particular gun, and it won't fit because of a matter of .25" widthwise.

But, be warned... it seems the review of air rifles are pretty reliable.  There just aren't any really dead-on accurate ones in the lower price ranges.

reviewText: I really don't like writing bad reviews, but in this case, I have to. This is the newer version of the Glacier Glove. This doesn't work well at all. The motion of opening your hands up fully causes too much tension on the glue of the cloves and they end up breaking at the seams. Brake cable housings are far too stiff to work with SRAM brakes which are easily affected by the push and pull of the cable housing. I had to discard them and use SRAM cables. POP ends aren't compatible with SRAM brakes leaving you with too few ferrules. Overall the cables have more friction than Shimano PTFE cables.

2 Stars because it will not keep any feed dry as advertised. At first it was just the feeder legs that got wet, swelled and clogged up the feeder so nothing was coming out. They I could smell the sour feed before I even got to the feeder. Opened it up, molded feed on the inside of the supposedly weather proof top. I had to pour out 100 pounds of molded rotting feed.
 First you either need really long arms or extra long tools to put this thing together. It is a two person job if you don't have really long arms and tools for sure. The design could be better with an internal bracket that actually seals the feeder legs. This would also make installing the legs easy rather than trying to hold each, both at arms length with a ratchet drive or wrench while reaching over with the other hand and trying to tread a washer and nut.
 I sealed the feeder legs with flex seal because no matter how tight you got the bracket and nuts, you can still see light peering through which means moisture can get in. Why they didn't design this with some sort of weather seal is beyond me as that is typically the number 1 issue causing gravity feeders getting clogged. The last thing is the hollow legs... why not sealed legs so the dirt/mud does not get in them causing rust, or adding a pedal on the ends?
 If you want this expensive feeder, don't buy it. Stick with a $80 broadcast feeder. If you do get this feeder, do not use anything except whole kernel feed corn or it will get wet from moisture build up in the plastic drum and rot/mold and clog the gravity feeder legs. What a waste of money!
summary: Pretty thin materiel for the price

reviewText: I have some zinging nerve issues when I ride, so I keyed off the reviews and bought these. Used them for two weeks, WITH gel bike gloves. They're too hard. They have (I can see now that I've cut them off my handlebars) only a maximum 2mm softer plastic for cushioning, over firmer flexible plastic. As cushioning grips, these fail. The heel-of-hand flanges are too thick to flex, so provide no extra cushioning. My recommendation is that you try before you buy. I just returned from the store with an $8 pair of Bell "Comfort Grips." They feel much softer.

I was excited about this light and it appears to be well made and is plenty bright. The mount is solid and easy to use. That being said the toggle switch is the critical flaw with this unit. If you place your weapon down on a hard surface the light can easily be switched on just from the weight of the firearm. This design really needs to be worked on for future releases. Update 4/20: I found that by loosening the bezel by a quarter turn will prevent the light from coming on even if the switch is engaged. It may be a way to prevent accidental battery discharge. reviewText: I just received these pads and immediately put them to use under my weight bench.  The foam pads interlock well and it's easy to set up. This is a cool skateboard, a lot of fun and maneuvers  fairly well. I have owned it and used it regularly for 5 months. There is 1 huge problem with it though. It's braking! (Or lack thereof) With its single wheel drive system, when the controller brake is activated to slow down, it bites very hard and only to the one rear wheel. At high speeds, it becomes very noticeable and dangerous. Especially downhill. When you need to slow down, even slightly pressing down on the brake will cause the rear end and board to get very squirly and wobbly. It is unpredictable as well.
I had not fallen until this last week. While riding downhill, I slightly began pressing down on the controller brake. The board twisted and began to wobble and went sideways. I tried to run off of it but went down. I broke my left arm at the elbow in the process.
Until they can make it brake safely (possibly with 2 wheel drive and braking) the board is dangerous. In my opinion, it should be recalled until a safe solution is found.
It speeds along well at 12mph flat ground but still the braking is an issue on even flat surfaces. If you need to stop somewhat quickly, you'll end up on your ass.
summary: The 1 wheel brake broke my arm

Review

I'm super disappointed.
istructed to buy techno thermal under layer garments  for Wilderness Search and Rescue, I figured this well known brand would do the job

Not.

And the thumb hole position and collar cut of this garment are an additional bummer.

If warmth is not what you need

Pros:
Good sewing and finishing - will probably last years.
Other than collar and thumb hole, cut is good.

Cons:
Very pricey.
NOT warm and doesn't wick as promised. Feels uncomfortably cold, slick and slimy when moist.
Collar too wide - neck loses heat - you have to add a scarf. Annoying.
Thumb hole aligns with little finger (wtf?). You could twist the sleeve but it makes an already uncomfortable garment even more annoying and uncomfortable.

Cut and Size:
I am a dumpy 5' 3" at 135 lbs. A Medium fits correctly- sleeves are good and long, hugs body and shoulders without constricting (I have broad rock climber's shoulders). Long body cut.

Just for interest and not for this review

Personally I get far more warmth if instead of a thermal under layer such as this garment, I wear a thin, knit layer made of a 3 fiber mix - with cotton for moisture/comfort/wicking, spandex for stretch/durability, plus a dash of wool for loft. Look out for Australian thin knits like this. They are warm, comfortable and are machine washable.
This reel is huge!!!! You really can't tell by the description...NO Anti-reverse.

I have a lot of laptop bags, backpacks, and cases that I've gone through trying to find whatever ends up being the best one.  My current favorite has lasted longer than most, my STM messenger bag.  It has plenty of individual small storage spots for things like USB sticks, portable hard drives, external CD drives, portable chargers, cables, etc...  For me that's the most critical thing in a laptop carrying bag of any type.  If all I want is a way to carry the laptop by itself with nothing more than a power cable, I can do that with a cheap, small padded sleeve.  If I want a bag where I have to throw everything into a single compartment then dig through it trying to find something every time I need it, I can buy just about any backpack that has a padded sleeve.  Finding something that's useful to me or my clients is tough.

This one isn't the worst thing I ever have seen, but it's far from even middle of the road when compared to all the others I've tried.  The whole "TSA friendly" concept that you can just unfold it but leave it in the bag is something I've never hit.  Milwaukee, Chicago, Atlanta, none of the other bags I've had have ever actually allowed this to happen.  I've *ALWAYS* been told to pull the laptop out of the case and put it in a separate tray.

There is only one compartment that has any small storage slots - and none of them have any kind of top to fold down to hold things in them.  There's only 3 sleeves in one of the compartments that are rather small and narrow, wouldn't fit any but one of my external drives (the small laptop type, not the larger 3.5" standard internal hard drive size).

So that leaves two full sized compartments for everything to just be shoved to mingle, leaving you to have to dig and find what you want, although they work well for clothes and such.  But again, I'm looking for a laptop bag, not a suitcase.  I have several suitcases for clothes, my laptop bag I just want something I can carry the things I need for my laptop, not a change of clothes.

Then there's the laptop sleeve itself, on the inside surface of the backpack right against the wearer's back. It's padded, but still a bit awkward with the solid rectangle of a laptop inside there.  And there's not any padding on the bottom where the laptop edge would be resting on the floor.  There's the folded over seam that forms the edge of the slot the laptop goes into, but it's not very protective.  I'd hate to be setting it down and misjudge slightly how close to the ground I was when I set it down, since it just doesn't feel very safe down there.

It can be awkward getting the laptop in and out as well, since this is under the straps.  They block the lower part of the opening.

It's well constructed though, the seams and stitching is top notch.  And I really do like the color.  But the small loop on top for carrying is just a web strap, no softness or padding for the times you're lugging it by that instead of over your shoulder.

All told, this just isn't something I'd carry my laptops around in.  I'll stick with my Pelican and STM bags.
summary: More negatives than positives for my use

reviewText: I liked the idea of these as an emergency light set to keep in my backpack for times when I was unexpectedly caught outside in the dark or a storm. Absolutely the best fishing tool I've ever owned!  I bought one two years ago and used it every weekend since, cleanly and safely de-hooking hundreds of fish, from sail cats, sharks and toothy mackerel to snapper, sea trout and red fish. Every guest on our boat is amazed at how easy and simple it is to use, and it's truly a rare event for us to ever actually touch a fish, whether we're releasing a fish or putting it in the fish box.

If it's so great, why only a two star rating?  Well, the original de-hooker was recently lost overboard, and since I never plan to go fishing again without one, so I purchased an exact replacement through Amazon - this 16" ARC. It was shipped and received within a few days, and we took it with us this past weekend, looking for sea trout, grouper and king mackerel in Tampa Bay.  Our first fish was a three pound mackerel so we whipped out the ARC to quickly release him.  Just like the hundreds and hundreds off times before with our previous ARC, I grabbed the leader in one hand and slid the de-hooker down to the hook and pulled tight to release the fish.  At that moment, the rod of the de-hooker snapped off at the handle and went flying into the sea.  Left with only the handle and one mad mackerel, which were both eventually lost overboard during the ensuing fire drill, we couldn't believe what had just happened.  I didn't even have anything to return for a replacement.

I've just now ordered my third one, and if it lasts as long as my first one, I'll come back and change the rating.  It's a great tool and hopefully we just got a rare defective one this time.
These did not work as expected and jammed continuously. Better get some with a brass casing instead of all plastic.

reviewText:
Just installed this and found that the included 1/2" bolt (as well as the Swagman locking model) would not thread into the rearmost of the two holes on the hitch bar / tongue. Seemed to work fine with the front hole, which was slightly larger, but moving the aluminum threaded insert back to rear hole (towards bikes) wouldn't work-- the hole will let the untreaded shaft of the bolt pass, but not the threaded part.

My Curt class 2 hitch (for 2007 Matrix XR) only has one hole in the more "rearward" position so my only choice was to drill the hitch tongue / bar up to 1/2". Worked fine after that but I think it's ridiculous that the rack doesn't work with both holes right out of the box.
summary: Had to drill hitch to fit the bolt it shipped with

I don't do many bad reviews. I'm pretty easy to please, but I cannot get over this product.

Like many who will be buying this tomahawk, I was spurred by Wranglerstar's review of it. He got it for $24, but once the video posted the demand pushed the price up to $38. I went for it anyway, due to the well made look that Cody's had. I knew that the edge would be non-existent and the haft would need a good fitting. What Cody's specimen didn't have was what caused me to take off 3 stars.

The Handle:
Let me start with the good part. I liked the handle. The grain ran at a 45 degree angle to the bit and was finished in a light wax. It does have a bit of heartwood in it, but I don't mind. The fit was good to the top if the eye, but had gaps at the bottom. This is not an uncommon problem on budget hawks. I generally ensure that the head doesn't move during use and not worry too much about it looking perfect.

The Head:
So mine came the same as Wranglerstar's, with about 1mm flat where the sides should meet to form an edge. I don;t think they intended to complete the edge, but just wanted to establish a bevel. Then things stared going south. The cheeks (sides) of the bit do have a nice rough finish and scale from forging and heat treating, but the top and bottom look like they were ground in the dark. The angle of the grind changes and multiple passes the don't line up. It looks like it was done by angle grinder and is similar to how metal looked when I first used the tool. I thought about trying to grind it flat myself, but considering I paid almost $40, I wanted something better than Cold Steel. This unfortunately is not it. The heads on the Cold Steels, while slathered in paint, are better finished.

Overall, if this were to cost $24, I might get one. Might. This would be after getting all the Cold Steel hawks, and all the offerings I like from Crazy Crow Trading Co. If you want something of similar size, weight and style Cold Steel Frontier Hawk. It will cost a few dollars more, but is much better than the hawk I rec'd. Strip the paint and the varnish from the handle and it you will find a tomahawk much better than this one.

Would not recommend.
summary: Would be a good tomahawk for $20.

reviewText: I really wanted to love this product. Cutting up giant pieces of moleskin to just the right size and then trying to get them to say in place is always a giant pain when you're on the trail. I liked the idea of having a bunch of pre-cut stuff in a handy little package and people seem really excited about the "GlacierGel." But when I broke these out on the trail I was glad I still had my moleskin and Leuko tape on hand (seriously, if you haven't tried Leuko tape and you get blisters you need to buy some right now). The moleskin patches seem to be made of a special kind of moleskin that is much thinner and less substantial than standard moleskin. The first time I tried to apply one to a big toe it just kept peeling off every time I put on my sock. I like the idea of the "doughnut" shape where the center of the blister is left exposed. In practice however, the moleskin isn't thick enough to make this work. The GlacierGel was equally impossible to keep in one place, and didn't seem to add much if anything to the equation. All in all it seems like something that looks great on the shelf at the outdoor store, but if you're serious about blisters you need to build up your own kit.
summary: Love the idea but was a total fail in practice

reviewText:
Well, ordered these booties for fishing. Had switched brands because of their slightly better price and some reviews.

Wore these for about 3 times on a fishing trip and the right bootie had a seem give out. It was simply poorly made.

Recently the company contacted me because of my complaint about the poor workmanship. I explained in a series of emails, and they then wanted me to ship it back for a "possible replacement". So, they wanted me to spend postage, gas to drive to post office, packaging etc etc. and a lot of time for a $13.00 neoprene bootie???

I explained all this, and they basically told me to take a walk, too bad for me.

Well, I hope this review will warn other people about the quality (or rather lack of the same) for their product.

Their customer service is simply lacking in how to gain l;oyal customers. I order 2 pairs of these a year, and fish with a lot of people on trips....

So, I will spread the word and also point to the extremely well made booties I now wear and will be recommending to my fishing buddies.

Buyer Beware here for sure.

PS...I gave them 2 stars because they shipped them fast and at least answered my complaint.
summary: Had switched brands because of their slightly better price and some reviews

The heads were all loose and the handle was extremely marred from someone forcing it onto a handle that isn't shaped properly to the heads. With each one it takes me about 2+ hours of filling and sanding to get the proper fit and even then run out of room on the end of the handle before it fits the way it should. reviewText: The eye relief is very short, so it doesn't work well with anything I own.  I bought it to go on top of a .22 cal rifle, a Ruger 10-22 to be exact.  At the time of purchase, the photos showed it with an offset mount which would help with the eye relief, but it was shipped with a centered mount.  I contacted them and they offered to send me an offset mount, but what I received was used.  It was scratched up and had glue or thread locker all over the screws and the mount.  The scope sits entirely too high for the 10-22 and I must crane my neck far forward, even using the offset mount.  I should have returned it.  A word of advise... The mount that it was shipped with will not work with a Weaver rail.  It is for a Picatinny rail only because of the large cross screws.  The offset rail has no cross screws so it works with either rail.  Since it has no cross screws, I don't expect it to stay in place while shooting.
i don't like, but ....
I loved it so much until it just broke. Just like that. Snap. In the trash. It was perfect until that. I never mistreated it. Just bad quality plastic.

Initially worked well, but after a couple of years the bearings no longer turned easily when pushing.  Several ball bearings apparently slipped out of the race inside since you could hear them rattling around inside.  It turns out that this product does not use self contained sealed ball bearing units with steel races like most other high end cleaning rods do, but rather loose balls that ride directly on the plastic of the handle structure.

On top of that, the handle unit is not rebuildable since the soft aluminum end nut is glued to the shaft at the factory and extremely difficult to remove without damage.

I should mention one caveat... my unit was bought about 15 years ago.  The design may have been improved since then.  I doubt it though, since the new units look identical in their construction.

reviewText: I have just started collecting replica BB guns. I have ten so far and this one is the least accurate. Out of a 20 round mag it will through 3 to 5 rounds 3" off in a random direction. It looks good and feels good in the hand. Lighter than the real fire arm. The trigger 'pull' is not stiff but the length of travel is long. I suggest firing in single action by manually cocking the hammer. Because it is not a 'blow back' you can get well over a hundred rounds per CO2 cartridge.

The grill side set off all the smoke detectors and left a greasey film on everything in my whole house and I was only using a med low burner, well, at least the door stopped squeeking! Just when you thought you've experienced all the unpleasantness of this pan, you then go to clean it and discover you'd be better off just throwing it out in the yard for the dogs to lick clean! I love you Lodge, I really do but I'll stick to outside grilling and my larger lodge skillet for hotcakes, the 13 inch round pan is a dream as are all the other pieces I own. As for this heavy sticky thing well, I may try it out on my fire ring next cookout and if that doesn't work out, it's yard sale time!

reviewText:
I really like the Basis health tracker. It is the most comfortable monitor that I've worn so far. The band is large enough to accommodate my wrist with four holes left over if I wear it comfortably snug, and three holes remain if I wear it loosely; I'm a six foot two man, who weighs about two-fifty.

The technology behind this monitor is fairly impressive. In typical use, this makes a fantastic watch. The time is displayed by default, while a touch of the lower left control dot will toggle to a display of the date in day name, calendar date and month format. The readout consists of unlit digits on a black background - it would be nice to have an option to display the inverse, although I am happy with it as it is. The top left dot temporarily enables the backlight. If lifting the watch up to look at the face of the watch, the backlight automatically comes on, which makes for convenient low light viewing.

Monitor functions are simple. There are top and bottom touch control dots on the right hand side of the watch, which cycle through calories burned, heart rate, steps taken. I haven't ridden my bike, but it interpreted my lawn mowing session as a bike ride, which will also be one of the cycle-through options if there is any time registered for the day. It may be that when motion is tracked without a swinging arm that it assumes bicycling. At least it registers the activity.

The numbers I get seem accurate overall, though early on I would occasionally read an astonishingly high or low heart rate, I'm not sure if this is because I was wearing it loosely, or if it was not in reading mode at the time - the heart symbol would be solid, whereas it displays a heart outline when normal readings show, but the compiled numbers appear to be acceptably correct.

The Basis Heath Tracker includes detailed information statistics when uploaded to my personal Basis account online. There, I can also view my sleep statistics. It has given proper details for the most part, but I have caught an instance where I was sitting and watching TV in the early morning that was reported as sleep. Between light sleep, heavy sleep and REM sleep, I am unsure how anything at the top of my wrist can indicate these things, but it tends to look believable, and my bed times and wake up times match up for the most part, so it does well at keeping track.

The watch itself is somewhat deep. It is quite compact for all of the features it entails, yet after several weeks of use, I have cut back on wearing it to bed. It's cool to track my sleep, but I like to conk out with an arm under my pillow as I lie sideways, and I get the princess and the pea effect with this hard metal square under my pillow. Sure, I get used to it or adjust until I drift off, but in the grand scheme of things, I know when I sleep, so as cool as it seems, I really don't need to look at it again on the computer.

In the early days of wearing my monitor, there was a recall on a competing product due to a rash. I wondered if it was a thing with monitors, because I was developing a rash on my wrist with this product. Being inquisitive as to cause, I realized that it may be that when I wash my face at night, and get that little bit of soap and water under the band and go to sleep on it, that it may have been the cause, and it was. I began the habit of removing the band when washing up and putting it back on dry before bed, and it went away. This is not something of which to be alarmed; when I was a dishwasher years ago, the same thing happened with my wrists after prolonged exposure to the stainless steel washer and constant contact with my wrists with hot soapy water - not sure why, but it was a thing. I was provided the 2014 Carbon Steel Edition of the Basis Health tracker, and it has the metal mounts for the band. I like the 2014 band for its low profile and sleek look.

The button on the side of the watch along the right is used to Enable Bluetooth when disabled, or it is used to Sync the Basis Monitor when Bluetooth is enabled, of by cycling to the next option with the touch dots along the right side of the face of the watch, I can disable Bluetooth when not in use. I like that I can upload my data through my iPhone via Bluetooth as a convenience option.

The Basis Health Tracker includes a charge cable, which can be placed over the face of the watch while worn at the computer. When I remove my watch from my wrist, a small green flicker on the underside of the monitor appears to be disconnecting from the Borg collective. It's kind of cool.

Overall, I like the Basis. I almost love it. The statistics are applied to habits, which one unlocks with points under the website account. The habits that encourage me, are the same habits which discourage me once I miss enough of them within a week to accomplish them. It still provides an easy way to tell where I'm faltering in my activity. If I achieve a habit in one week, it increases the multiplier for that habit the next week. It's like a fun, points-accumulating game in that regard. When the multiplier goes up, so does the number of successful days required to achieve that particular habit.

The Basis 2014 Edition is a wonderful health monitor, and an even cooler watch. It looks great, it is quite comfortable, and the depth of the face is the only thing that may ever get in the way of anything, but still, it's fairly compact. I like that it is a highly functional, wrist-only solution. I've tried the Omron strap and band combo, and I've tried a pay-to-play arm band endorsed by a weight loss show. I still love my Omron, but its wristwatch is ridiculously uncomfortable, and I stopped using my pay-to-play as soon as my free subscription ran out - mainly I couldn't stand the chore of the manual nutrition entry. The Basis, is by far, even still an enjoyable unit, even after I've given up on caring about sleep patterns. It holds about a four day charge, though I've gone longer. It's still fun to use, I enjoy the convenience of checking on my daily progress, and it is an absolutely stylish and gorgeous watch with cool features and controls.

=======
UPDATE:

09-29-14 (about six months later)

I may as well hurry up and update to compare longevity, in that within the last month I have been having issues with the watch, of which the only abuse it may have received is whacking against a counter corner while I walk through the house. Anyway, the problems are that I have had to hard reset the Basis whenever my silver dots become non-responsive - I took a guess and held down the side button, to which after several seconds it would flash off, and then work properly afterward...for a while...perhaps as little as five minutes sometimes, or long stretches, it varies.

I wore this watch day in and day out. I tried to keep it up on charges, but had difficulty keeping up with it, whether every four days got tedious, or if it wasn't quite going four days anymore, which is what I suspect. The last time I wore it, I got an out of memory error.

I just saw this has been discontinued by the manufacturer, so I'll just leave it at that. It's still a wonderful watch, lighting up when flipped, and all, but yeah...its pretty much done.
summary: I (Used To) Almost Love It - My (Previous) Favorite Health Tracker So Far - (Updated)

reviewText: I was excited to get this bike.  It took a little time to put together, but wasn't hard. So, I ended up returning this item. It wasn't a horrible product for the first few days, just wasn't for me.

Pros:::
+So this thing is pretty compact. The room I set it up in isn't to big and when I finally got it assembled, it doesn't take up much space at all. Folded up I almost was able to fit it into the closet and moving it from room to room was pretty easy.
+Light weight. Very easy to move, easy to maneuver
+Easy set-up. Didn't take me long at all to assemble. Had it working before an episode of Dexter ended.

Cons:::
-So, the belt started sticking to the surface pretty much by the end of the next day. I used some of the lubricant that was recommended to get it going again, but it just started sticking again after an hour. I read that some other people were experiencing this, doesn't seem to be happen to every machine, but it was really frustrating having the random skip while trying to walk on it.
-Felt flimsy. The rails didn't feel very solid at all. But, I guess I got what I paid for. But man, those things would shake, tilt, and just not really want to stay solid. Didn't make using the machine very comfortable.
-Just enjoyable overall. The overall experience of using this machine wasn't really something I would like to repeat.

Overall:::
The sticking made using the machine unbearable. I returned it, bought one with a motor, and am much happier with my new buy. Sure, its huge and takes more room and I can't move it from place to place, but the new treadmill doesn't feel flimsy like this one and is more enjoyable to use. If you're looking to save a buck, skip this. Just buy a cheap motorized one.

The neck area is very short ... the picture makes it seem like it long but really is not and once you tie up your helmet strap it no longer covers your neck anymore. Also the small area on the back with the velcro is so small where it attaches that the velcro edges itself scrape on the back of your neck and really is uncomfortable the whole time and you are constantly moving it around so it's not scraping.
I kept it to put in my gear back as a backup for the few bucks it cost but I will never wear it again unless I have to.
Bought a quality $20 full breathable mask and it has a long neck area (even when tied up with helmet strap) and dones not have to horrible velcro in back to scrape my neck all day.
I do not recommend buying this.
summary: I do not recommend buying this!

Do yourself a favour and DO NOT PURCHASE this brand, unless you are prepared to spend $ every year or so to buy a new one.
