I bought this as a gift for my sons and, of course, for myself as well.  We don't use it a lot, so I can't speak to how well it holds up to everyday use, or out in a survival type situation.  I can tell you though that it is quite fun throwing it at a wooden target in my backyard.  While this certainly isn't authentic in design or physical appearance to those used by Native Americans, and Frontiersmen in the Eastern Woodlands long ago, one still feels a connection to that heritage as you become more skilled at sticking it in the target and hitting what you aim at.  Its a lot of fun for adults, and for kids, providing they are supervised by the adults.  For being a backyard Daniel Boone, or a suburban Tecumseh, it certainly fills the bill.  It also has a "cool" modern look to it as well.  Haven't gotten good enough with it yet to whack squirrels or rabbits in the backyard, but I hope to reach that happy goal someday.  Here's a tip though: when you first start tossing this around, put the family dogs in the house.  The instinct to avoid falling prey to wildly flung battle-axes has apparently been bred out of the typical American canine over the intervening 260 years.  I am happy to report no injuries or fatalities to man or domestic beast, just some close calls I'd rather not repeat.  Happy chucking.

I would be remiss though if I didn't address the whole Made in China issue.  Designed in the USA is fine.  I mean, those American designers draw checks too, but say that.  Don't say its made here if it isn't.  Don't insult our intelligence with trickery and deception.  I bought THIS hawk because it was the only one among the cheaper set that was allegedly, made in the USA.  Us hunters, fishermen, and other outdoorsmen tend to care deeply whether or not a product is manufactured in the USA. I will pay more for a product to get one that is American designed AND made.  I don't care if the company is foreign-owned.  As long as they employ American workers here making their products (Toyota, Honda, Bridgestone, etc) I'll buy it over anything made elsewhere.  Especially the total crap that's made by our number one enemy in the World: China.  However, that's a whole other story for another time.  If you are going to make products that attract and interest American outdoorsmen, then it would behoove you to build a factory in one of the fifty states and hire you some American workers.  As long as Buck and Ka-Bar still make their products in the USA, I'll keep buying them to the exclusion of SOG.  Your product is fun, but it is tainted by lies.

Not a quality product- the price is attractive, but the rail is too long, precludes using the rear sight, and the screws tend to strip.  Buy the GG&G, and don't waste time and money on these.  They are basically a rip off of the GG&G design anyway.

I'm disappointed with these push-up bars. From the picture, you can't tell they're cheaply made - lightweight plastic. I used them on a hardwood floor and once was enough. The bottom of each one has rubber pads to keep you from sliding, but they are poorly set and feel flimsy.  They're positioned to stick out slightly to provide some traction but once you put your weight on them, they get compressed and become one with the bars. As a result, they can't keep you locked in place. I used them once and already I was concerned they would slip out from under me. I was hoping to replace my old, trusty push-up bars, but not this time.
summary: Cheaply Made, Not Sturdy - Inferior Bars That Slide

reviewText:
I have a pair of BATES RAT Boots that a new puppy of ours chewed the laces off. I searched high and low for replacement and came across these. I got the three pack so I would have more if needed and I am glad I did. These don't even come close to what was on my boots before, these are thinner and like to stretch and they come apart quickly. Ive worn out soles of boots, even boots, but I have never had issue with the laces until now. One of the three pair right away frayed and are useless and im just working at the Farm, no serious extreme use. I currently have the second pair of three on my boots and they are starting to show signs of excess wear already. I will not ever buy these again. I guess if I cant find proper replacement Ill just use 550 cord, this is ridiculous.

Pros: Cheap, easy availability and they do lace faster, great temporary laces

Cons: Cheap, thin, wear out rapidly, smaller in diameter and stretch more than they should, junk IMO

The untensil slides down into the orange handle.  Nifty idea to save space, but there's a gap between the utensil and handle when it's retracted which makes me wonder if it will break when I pack it in with all of my things.

Aside from carrying the jetboil name, there's no real synergy with the other jetboil products.  These don't fit into the jetboil canister, don't fit nicely in the sleeve, etc.  I was disappointed with that.

And again, do you really need a camping spatula?

I think skip this product and find a good quality spork.
summary: Do you really need a camping spatula?  No, go buy a spork.

I'm actually not sure that I like this. Self-massagers have been historically disappointing, but after a hard day, I'm always tempted to try yet another one to see if it will actually help out with back and shoulder aches.
After having this for a week or so, I think I have more complaints about it than accolade. First, the product description seems to imply that you can use this product on your own. I tried, and I found that solo operation is both ridiculous looking and feeling. Because of the length of the item, I found that I cannot get it to roll down my back at any comfortable angle. I think this would only be possible were one a contortionist and able to dislocate one or both shoulders. I also found that, solo, I cannot apply the pressure I need.

Another complaint has to do with the "customizability" of the product: it's just... not, really. While you can certainly remove some or even most of the rings, there is nothing on the rod that will set the place of the remaining rings, causing them to move around haphazardly while the product is in use. There *is* a small bit of friction, but there is not a "ring lock" or anything like that.

Yet another complaint involves the structure of the ring-holding rod: it's basically plastic, and not even particularly hard plastic. You can bend this thing pretty easily. Imagine trying to roll a lump of dough with a 2-foot section of steel cable or thin PVC pipe: it flattens the very top of the dough, but then bows out in the middle and compresses on the ends, still leaving a rounded section in the middle of the dough lump. The malleability of the rod essentially makes it impossible to apply the pressure I need to my back and shoulders -- I can't roll out the lumps in my muscles well enough, or evenly enough.

Another: the exercise guide that the product description says the item contains is actually downloadable content, not an actual book or leaflet: so, when you receive the item, there will be yet more to do. And if you're like me, you won't even download the guide, but rather just start using the product on its own.

The one positive is that the product, for what it is, actually feels relatively nice -- better than nothing at all, certainly -- IF you have someone else helping you out. But it's not a miracle massager by any means, as I hope this review has shown. Unless you're super sore, don't expect to melt into a puddle with the Gaiam.

If your pedal uses a wrench instead of a hex key, then a 1/2 by 1/8 will also work, and will be slightly more accurate, but you'll never dig it out of the hole until the pedal is removed.

If you're stuck with aluminum, brass, or titanium pedal axles, then you may want to put a blob of clear "Shoe Goo" on this before strapping it down, and let that cure for a day.  That will keep it in place better.

I wanted to love this gauge but overall it was something that I found not very useful. I use it for my mountain bike.
-When checking pressure, it's hard to get it over the stem without loosing a lot of air. You have to get it right and push quickly and firmly to seat it. Even after many tries, I get it 50% of the time right but often just miss and loose air.
-The digital readout is in whole numbers for psi which really sucks. For Bar pressure it is in tenths. So in Bar it would read 2.5 Bar but in psi it is 35 psi instead of 35.5, missing the tenth is really bad for a bike pressure.
-If you want to release pressure with this one, you have to select the "Adjust" button which is an unnecessary step that cumbersome.
-The head of it rotates but not enough so often you have to move your bike value to new position.

Hope this helps

Before purchasing the Ezip1000 I owned and used the Ezip750 for about 1 month daily (no complaints with the 750 other than speed and ability to go up hills). I had to send back the 1st order for my Ezip1000 because the battery cover did not fit and the back brake was messed up. The brake was basically pressed at all time due to the rotor not being straight. This slowed down the scooter and made a very unpleasant sound. The replacement was just as bad but at least the battery cover fit. I took the scooter to a bike shop and they were able to loosen the brake and straiten the rotor a little to minimize the rubbing.
The power is good and the ride is very smooth thanks to the front and rear suspension. I would give this 5 stars if it was made better. The fact that 2 scooters came with bent brake systems is a problem. I did not have this problem with the 750. If you purchase this scooter I suggest you bring it to a bike shop and have the brakes inspected to make sure they are not rubbing because this will slow you down and put unnecessary pressure on the engine.
Also note that I have not been able to go more than 6 mile without the battery dying. I am ok with this because I only need it to go 2 miles each way for my daily commute. I am very happy with the power and the ability to go up hills. I did replace the seat for a more comfortable one, the stock seat is not bad but I am picky when it comes to bike seats.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying I've spent the last 6 months researching tents, buying tents, setting them up, and in the end returning all of them. I bought the Columbus Grand Canyon, the Coleman Rockwall, and an Alpine Design tent that was discontinued, finally I was able to get the "crown jewel of tents" on sale at Cabela's for $90.00 because it was a display. To say the least I was ecstatic at my good fortune. I took it home and after 1.5 hours of struggling by myself to set this up I figured it out (first set up is a truly a pain if you don't have a partner helping you). I set it up and it looked glorious. We were expecting storms so I took down the tent and waited a week to set it up again in the yard. This time when setting up the tent, not one but both bay window poles splintered badly one stabbing me in the hand-I was very unhappy. I called and they are going to send me replacement parts hopefully those will be better. I think the tent is a good size for a family of 4; 2 queensize beds fit with room to spare for gear. I wouldn't dream of packing 8 people in this tent. The ventilation with windows open was very good (zero condensation).  I tend to think in lists so I'll run down good bad and otherwise.

Good: Size-large but no so huge you would have a hard time fitting it on a site, Venting, lots of airflow is always good, Sturdy-aside from the window poles when this tent is set it feels substantial, Water repellancy-while every other tent says to spray them with repellant this one specifically says not to (except seams); Color I like the color palate for this tent -not gaudy but not boring

Bad: Snapping poles in bay windows hopefully this is addressed with higher quality replacements sent from manufacturer. Also my orange center poles show signs of stressing at joints. I know how to use shock corded poles so I'm not just partially inserting them. I bought a cheapy tent at Target years ago and have used it dozens of times with no pole damage. Room Divider-while most room dividers hang in place with toggles this one is sewn to the floor and sticks up about 4 inches HUGE tripping hazard.

Other: Since I've recently tried 4 family tents I can tell you that this tent is missing several amenities that I liked in the Coleman Rockwall: Rigid door, self rolling windows and integrated lighting...Rockwall was HUGE and had some durability issues but those features were really really nice.

Overall I'm not going to give this tent 4 stars because Northpole obviously has quality issues with their poles, customer service was aware of a quality issue (a bad batch -is what they said) and yet they shipped these with bad poles. Since most of the reviews have had poles snap on 1st or 2nd setup I don't think quality control was rigorous enough-now I'm going to be waiting 3 weeks for replacements from the manufacturer.

UPDATE 1 ***I have received the replacement poles (About 10 days after calling)They appear to be more rigid than the first set and different colors (I'm actually kinda bumbed that the orange ones were replaced with olive colored ones). I will test them out soon and see if they break or deform like the first ones. Hopefully the hasslefree replacement parts will solve the problem and make this the family tent for the next 10 years. I'll update with results if these are crummy too.

UPDATE 2 ***Went camping 3rd time in this tent and used the new replacement poles. The replacement window poles are definitely more rigid than the originals and a little longer. EXTREMELY difficult to thread into place and get both end caps in slot provided...I was very carefull because the originals broke so easily but these were really hard to get in. Kinda bummed that the zipper on the expandable gusset part of the bag broke off completely leaving the bag in the fully expanded position, this is not a huge deal but I was not ruffing the bag up at all and the zipper busted off. The new top poles replacing the orange ones felt about the same after first time up they show no signs of deformity. I really like the ventialation options in this tent (it was warm in the day so we opened it up and cool at night so we just left open the cyclonic vents) but I'm seeing the same quality here that I saw with Coleman; Greatland; Columbus; Northern Territory, and Alpine Design...Definately not worth the price as similar quality/size/amenities can be had for less.

UPDATE 3 ***Went camping 3 more times in this. Had window poles snap again on me and had seam come apart at door zipper. Once again Columbia came through and replaced both tent skin, tent bag, and poles. From that perspective I'm extremely happy with the warranty. However I've heard they'll no longer honor warranty claims on my purchase (I haven't had any additional claims so I'm not 100% sure on that) My understanding is that this tent has been redesigned and is now much better than it was. During our only camping trip with rain we did experience leaks in both bay windows so I treated the seams all throughout the inside of the tent. Our next trip we did not have rain so I don't know if seam sealing will solve this problem or not. I think that there is no 'perfect tent'and really you just have to weigh the features that you find most valuable. I think my next camping purchase will be a popup camper and i'll be leaving the tent behind. Happy camping
summary: No "Group-Think" Review 3 Updates 3 years experience with this product

I purchased a Super Turbo 800watt Elite from Super cycle & scooters for myself. Boy what a difference. 6-7mph faster,longer run times,full suspension front and back,triple disks brakes vs one on the e-zip. Build quality is a giant step forward in short I returned the e-zip and bought another 800 Elite. Cost less than $100.00 extra and worth twice that in features,performance,safety and quality. Best decision I made in a long time and I am 70yrs. young. I am sure if my Grandson had ridden both scooters he would have said good move "Pops".

I was thew Shooting Sports Director at our local Scout Camp this year.  As such, we repaired several hundred arrows over this summer season.  The arrows were carbon with some aluminum ones as well.  All arrow shafts needing fletching were properly prepared including a thorough scraping and following it up with denatured alcohol.  After attaching the fletching, an extra drop of glue was added to the front and rear of each fletch for strength.  All arrows were stored vertically and the glue was left to set for a good 24 hours before the arrows were allowed to be used.
  By the time camp was over, we had about 5 arrows still in good condition.  I had fletching falling off before the arrows even hit the targets.  Others stripped off after hitting the targets.  In general, the glue seemed to hold on the arrow shafts about 80% of the time, but it stripped off of the plastic fletching.  In any case,I would not recommend this product in the future. 12/28/13 UPDATE:  I have been in contact with the manufacturer & they have sent new sample to try.  This sample just worked much better than The bottle of glue from Carbon Express.  I will be trying both out again over the next few months.

This isn't the first Emerson wave knife I have bought, but it is the first I have gotten from Kershaw. I'm a little disappointed.

First, out of the box, the knife is very stiff and hard to open, even by hand. I added a drop of oil and tried to loosen the screw a little bit. After playing around with it for a few minutes, it started to loosen up. I had a hard time getting the knife to deploy with the Emerson wave feature out of my pocket before loosening it up. It's a nice feature, but with the knife as small and stiff as it is, I think speedsafe opening (like from the Leek or Blur) might fit most people better. The thumb disk is for one handed opening, but good luck with getting the knife open one handed before loosening it up. That is the initial problem I have with the knife, the main feature doesn't work very well out of the box. It will loosen eventually, but it was really tight. The thumb disk is a questionable inclusion as well, I don't know why Kershaw didn't just use a thumb stud. A disk normally provides some extra grip for the thumb when holding the knife, but the wave feature hook on the top of the knife completely blocks the disk. At least there is some jimping on the hook.

The blade comes razor sharp. My blade didn't look completely straight. I read some of the other questions and reviews and looked closely at the knife, and sure enough, it looks like the grind is uneven. The blade is sharp, even though the grind appears to be uneven. Visually, the knife looks fairly elegant, but there are some things I don't like, besides the uneven blade. The choice to only have one side of the handle is G-10 is a really strange one to me. The blade oxide finish on the other side isn't as grippy as my Leek. There is a pocket clip, but this knife doesn't sit very deep in the pocket and about 0.75" seems to stick out of the pocket. My personal preference is for knives that sit deeper in the pocket (like many SOG knives tend to) but to each their own. Finally, it is made in China. I'm not the biggest fan of that.

This is a cool knife to add to a collection, especially if you don't have an Emerson wave style knife. It won't be going into my EDC rotation anytime soon. It looks elegant, but I wish they did better QC of it. For the price, definitely a good deal, but I don't think I will be buying the rest of the Kershaw/Emerson series if they are of the same quality. I would recommend a Kershaw Leek over this.

reviewText: These wrist stabilizers work fine. They're comfortable, easy to adjust, and the padding does what it's supposed to. No complaints about performance. However, after using them for about five weeks (three times per week), I'm already noticing some fraying on the edges of the stabilizing straps. It's nothing major at all, and it doesn't really affect the performance of the wrist padding (yet), but if it's happening after five weeks of use, my thoughts naturally turn to where the material condition will be in, say, five months. My recommendation instead of these are these Schiek Sports Ultimate Wrist Supports. They hold up better and provide the same wrist support. (As an aside, the Schiek supports are US-made, unlike the HumanX product. I'm not lowering my review score for this, of course, but the country of manufacture is important to a lot of people, which is why I mentioned it.)
summary: Good performance, but not as durable as they should be; not made in the USA

My husband was looking for a day pack. I bought him 6 backpacks to compare. The Hiking Cycling Backpack, Sunhiker Sports Outdoor Backpack Bag Running Camping Backpack Water Resistant Lightweight SMALL Daypack 25L M441 (Black), the Osprey Packs Momentum 22 Daypack (Spring 2016 Model), Carbide Grey, the Outlander Packable Handy Lightweight Travel Hiking Backpack Daypack, Grey, the Lightweight Rucksack 25L for men women kids - Foldable into Inner pocket (BLACK), the Cycling Hiking Backpack Sunhiker Water Resistant Travel Backpack Lightweight SMALL Daypack M0714 (Dark Green), and the Free Knight 25L Packable Handy Lightweight Travel Backpack Daypack-Lifetime Warranty (New Grey). There were pros and cons for each pack. He decided to keep the Hiking Cycling Backpack, Sunhiker Sports Outdoor Backpack Bag Running Camping Backpack Water Resistant Lightweight SMALL Daypack 25L M441 (Black)because it met his needs the best. We ordered all packs in gray, green, or black. We returned the other 5 packs. I liked 2 of the lightweight foldable packs - the Outlander Packable Handy Lightweight Travel Hiking Backpack Daypack, Greyand the Free Knight 25L Packable Handy Lightweight Travel Backpack Daypack-Lifetime Warranty (New Grey). I decided to order those for myself in Pink and Purple. All of the packs had a mesh pocket on each side of the pack for water bottles. We tested them all with a Nalgene bottle and a bottle of water. All of the packs could easily hold the bottle of water. Some were a very tight fit for the Nalgene bottles. All packs had a main compartment with one or two pockets in the front of the pack. The main compartments varied from 561 cubic inches to 1386 cubic inches. 3 of the packs were lightweight, foldable, and storable in their own pocket. Here are my summaries of this pack: 960 cubic inches 16 x 10 x 6 6 1/2 mesh pockets Bottle holder covers about 5 1/2 of the bottle Straps 2 1/4 wide Waist strap extends to about 37 This pack has 3 main compartments. The main zippered compartment is in the back. 2 front zippered compartments small one on the front. Middle sized one in middle Pros: - Fabric felt very durable - Easy to adjust chest strap up and down as well as tighten and loosen - Adjustable waist strap (see cons) - Handle at top of pack for an additional way of carrying it - Easy to adjust shoulder straps - Shoulder straps were mesh covered with the nylon fabric - padded and comfortable - Side pockets are mesh reinforced with fabric at sides and bottom (see cons) - Small zippered pouch inside the large compartment - Large pocket inside on the back of the large compartment - 1 extra loop on outside bottom of pack. - Extra side support straps Cons: - Pack was semi sturdy but didn't keep its shape as well as other packs with stronger back support panel - Some padding on the back panel - Waist strap very short better for thin adults or kids - Side pockets are very tight for a Nalgene bottle. I got one in but it was difficult. Worked fine for 16 oz water bottles. This was too small for my husband's needs. It was too heavy and not foldable, so it didn't meet my needs. We returned it.
summary: Small but sturdy pack for kids and small adults

reviewText: This holster is not bad depending what you are looking for....If you want a neat looking tactical leg holster for range use I would say this thing is excellent. The straps are long, especially on me so if I was keeping them I would have to cut them but that's not a big deal. Unfortunately I was looking for a leg holster for this hunting season and this is not going to work. It is not stable for constant walking and hiking like i'll be doing, the mag holder DOES NOT fit glock or double stack magazines by the looks of it. Biggest deal breaker there... Also the thumb release could be better. And it will also probably drag down your belt....Like I said not a bad holster, it has sturdy construction just not good for taking on any "Tactical" things. It will be flimsy and if you tighten it to where its not you'll cut your circulation. Ive had mines of for a few minutes after trying it on and I still feel the straps around my leg.

reviewText:
Update to last review:
Agyrr using the scope for a while it is great during the day but nighttime sucks. For one the lighted textile is too bright. When I try to put it on the lowest setting it moves and the brightness washes out the image. Second thing is that the scope does not gather enough light. I was hunting hod the other night at about 80 yards. There was a green led game light lighting the feeder area and a group on 8 hogs showed up. I only do head or neck shots and could not see good enough to make a good shot. Not wanting to just lob bullets at them I passed. I did some night vision testing at home with all my scopes and put my Nixon 3x9 back on as it had the v
Best view. The one thing I wish the Nixon had is the target turrets. I shoot both .223 and .22LR. Target turrets make sighting in and caliber changes quick and easy. My next scope will have good light transmission at night, target turrets, and hopefully a dim lighted textile that does not wash out the image. Finial score - great day scope but sucks at night.
summary: great day scope but sucks at night.

On the positive side, the tires mounted easily and the flat protection seems very good. I ride on some nasty roads, so flat protection is extremely important. The center tread is smooth rolling and takes little effort to get the bike up to speed. This tire doesn't perform well in loose, sand or gravel, so its best use is on pavement and hard packed or paved bike trails.

If you just need some cheap compression shirts to exercise in, these are cheap and seem well-made.
There is a caveat though: you can't wear a backpack because of the myriad of seams on the back of the shirt. They look unique, and you'll get used to them but they will chafe under a backpack. I often wear compression shirts when I'm hiking or backpacking, and even with a 15lbs daypack the seams on the back of these shirts are annoying at best. I tried my 55lbs trekking pack (just to say I did) and I didn't even have to move for the seams to irritate me.
These shirts are also a little looser than other compression shirts around the stomach/abs. I have a 36" chest, 30.5" waist, so I'm a bit smaller in that area than most guys who wear a men's medium, but UA and Tesla are fine while this shirt was not snug around my abs.
summary: Seams on the back are a problem with a backpack; not as tight around the abs.

As you can see from the picture below, this rower comes out of the box  with more than a few pieces.
After laying everything out and double checking the parts list, I started out trying to put this rower together.
My first word of advice is to use your own tools. The Allen Wrenches were the only useable tools that came with the rower.
The first step, went easy enough, but when it came to using the screwdriver to put on the chain covers, the first of two screws stripped.  So, I went and found a screwdriver in the garage to try to remove the second-same thing.  I think they were painted on, because they did not budge.
Okay, so like many exercise equipment manuals, the directions are worded in such a manner that they read like the writer's first language is not American English.  It was easier to figure things out by looking at the diagrams.
Because the chain covers are not necessary for operation, I was able to exercise on the rower for 5 minutes.
I do work out every morning, so it takes a bit of work to get my heart rate into aerobic mode.  I used all three cables (out of three) and rowed as quickly as possible and my heart rate only moved up to 100.  (This is using my own personal HRM.  The machine does not come equipped with one.)
Overall, I was disappointed with the quality, but it is a better machine, exercise wise, than my less expensive rower, so it gets 3 stars.
I would recommend this rower for a beginning exerciser, but not for an intermediate or advanced person.

While a pretty nice system, I agree with the other reviewers that the assembly is overly difficult and a 2 person job.  The worst part of the design consists of the three main posts that require some serious pounding and a very flimsy base that you either fill with sand or water/non-toxic anti-freeze.  I couldn't even begin to imagine how you would drain the sand out of the base if you ever needed to move it, so I chose to use water, and because we live in CT, we added the instructed 2 gallons of non-toxic anti-freeze.  The hoop worked well for almost a year and my family really enjoyed it, but this morning, we just noticed that the base is leaking the water and anti-freeze all over the driveway.  It has been below freezing as it is winter, but it has also been one of the mildest winters on record.  The base has no visible damage that we can see.  So now we need to spend the day draining and storing the system so it doesn't end up falling over and killing somebody.  We've also put a call into Spalding and I will report back how that experience goes.
summary: Base Leaking in Winter With Instructed 2 Gallons of Anti-Freeze

reviewText:
When the lingering summer warmth suddenly gave way to more seasonal October chill, I was dismayed to find that my cool weather riding tights, which had been packed away for the last six months, were nowhere to be found.  I ride year-round, logging 2500-300 miles annually, mainly through a 20 mile commute to work several times a week.  With no bike shop nearby, I turned to Amazon Prime to get my out of my "tight bind."

BOTTOM LINE: While the price point is excellent, and they seem reasonably well constructed, I had several issues that will prevent me from buying more or recommending them to others.  I still gave them two stars because the price and quality was good, and my issues mainly deal with fit.  I am a reasonably proportioned 5'10" adult male that doesn't usually have fit issues; nevertheless, others may find the fit to be perfect for them.

Let me go into specific detail for my rating:

ISSUE #1: BELL BOTTOMS?!  When the Amazon box arrived, I tried the tights on.  While the waist and thighs seemed a bit snug, it wasn't so bad as to warrant a larger size, and I figured a day of riding would form them to my specific physique.  However, when I suited up for an actual ride this morning, I was surprised at how loose the ankles were when I zipped them up.  The inside of the cuff has a gummy material designed to prevent the pant from riding up.  However, there was so much fabric that the pant didn't actually grab my ankle.  How this manifested on my ride was that during the downhill runs, I got a chilly draft on the lower six inches of my leg.  Since these are cool weather tights, not cold weather ones (it was 50 this morning), this is not a catastrophic flaw.  However, I thought it was an idiosyncrasy worth mentioning.

ISSUE #2: SKINNY KNEES.  As my ride progressed, I found the material bunching uncomfortably at the back of my knees.  While this provided merely a petty annoyance on my 20 mile ride, I imagine it could become more of an issue on a longer haul where chafing could result.

ISSUE #3: POOR CHAMOIS PLACEMENT.  This was the deal breaker for me.  I found the chamois padding to be way too forward in the tights.  As a result, when I rode, much of the padding was in front of my crotch rather than under my seat.  While this resulted in some nice insulation for the family jewels on the chilly morning ride, the downside was that my sitz bones, the actual pressure point of my seat, was at the extreme back edge of the padding.  Furthermore, the rest of my gluteus was completely unprotected.  So, while the rest of my backside doesn't serve as a pressure point, it is still in contact with my seat.  I could actually feel the rivets on the back of my Brooks saddle through the thin, unpadded material!  I noticed this misfit immediately and stopped to see if I had put the tights on backward.  I hadn't, but I tried hiking up the back of the pants while wearing the front droopy.  This helped for about 1/4 mile until the material returned to its natural position through my normal body movements.

I may try wearing my normal bike shorts under these tights to address this issue, but I suspect that the double padding will result in too much of a "diaper effect" to be a viable solution.  Since these tights were inexpensive and I've already ridden in them, I probably won't return them.  However, I am sure they will find their way to the back of my riding apparel drawer only to come out in a pinch when everything else is in the laundry.

UPDATE: Within 24 hours of posting the review above, I was contacted by the company apologizing for the issues I experienced with these tights, and offering to make things right.  While nothing has changed about the product, that response alone garnered another star in my rating; excellent customer service goes a REALLY long way in my book.  I will work with the company and amend my review even further pending the outcome of this interaction.

I'll be returning this jacket, mainly due to the cheap zipper that I find very difficult to zip.  I really liked the color of the jacket, and the sleeves were a perfect length on me.  Also,  I was looking for something with a lot of pockets.  This has 6 total, all on the outside.  It would have been nice to have at least  one more inner security pocket on the inside.  I did like the two cargo pockets on the outside, plus two roomy chest pockets, though I would have preferred their zips on top instead of the sides so things won't fall out if you leave them unzipped.  I mostly put car keys in pockets like these, and I wouldn't want to loose them.  The side hand warmer pockets had a very small opening and were a bit too small for my hands when wearing mittens.  I also found the cut of the coat two snug along the bottom.  The snugness seemed like a good idea to keep the wind out, but it was too tight to comfortably sit down, and that cheap zipper didn't have a bottom pull that could open up the coat a couple of inches at the bottom when sitting.  By contrast, the hood on this thing was gigantic and came down over my eyes.  The hood has no way to adjust it smaller, and  is not removable.

I'm disappointed to have to return this, since it almost meets my needs, and I haven't found anything better yet (since an old old coat of mine that had 8 pockets all in perfect places).  This coat also seemed like it would be fairly warm, but having to struggle with the zipper every time is a deal breaker.
summary: Almost a keeper, except for the horrible zipper.

My husband and I found this pillow impossible to inflate until we took a small, thin nail and punched holes in the area at the base of the mouthpiece, inside of its tube, right where it leads into the interior of the pillow. Inexplicably, the manufacturer had not left this area free and clear, so no air could get through! Even after punching the holes, it was still a pain to inflate, and it is not something I will want to do very often.

This was a big disappointment to me. I need lumbar support when sitting on hard chairs, but it is a hassle to carry around a small pillow everywhere I go. I had hoped to use this as a portable pillow that I could take with me uninflated in my purse and blow up at will. So much for that plan!

In terms of being an effective lumbar pillow when it is inflated, however, this pillow is actually quite decent. And as expensive as most lumbar pillows are, this one is a real bargain if used in that way.

You might want to be aware that this product emits strong PVC fumes, and I recommend airing it out before sleeping on it in an enclosed space (if using it when camping, this would be less of a problem).

You will definitely want to put a pillow case over this pillow if you are going to cushion your head with it. The feel of a plastic surface, whether smooth on one side or "flocked" on the other, is not enjoyable to press your cheek against. Not only that, it is rather hard and inflexible for a head pillow. You could end up with a neck ache.
summary: Really hard to inflate by mouth

We bought this for our family of 6 after returning a Coleman Weathermaster that was a pain to put up and leaked. This was a pleasant change. We did a dry run in our backyard, and when we took it to the campground it took us about 10 minutes to set up from unzipping the bag to putting in the last stake. It's a great-looking tent (we actually had a complement on it from a stranger), very spacious, very well-ventilated. The room dividers are nice, but it would be good to have other spots to hang them from for a little more customization. Also, the instructions have you put the rain fly up after the tent is up, but as another reviewer stated that's easier said than done. We found that if we shortened one side of the tent, slid the rain fly on, and then re-extended the poles it works great. We haven had it in rain yet, but the seams on the rain fly are taped, whereas the Coleman's weren't. Overall, great tent, but we'll update the review once we've had it in wet weather.

Edit 7/29/16: the tent actually does quite well in the weather. We've spent several nights in pretty solid rainfall with minimal leaking. The leaking has come near the doors and the seams along the sides, but it's really not too bad.

Our issue has been with the durability. The second time we used it we noticed a hole on the floor and in the ceiling. Since then we've patched several holes. The holes seem to be at points where the joints are rubbing against the fabric in storage. We've been very careful handling it and storing, not sure what the issue is, but this simply has not proved as durable as other tents have for us. However, for $300 it's still a good tent.
summary: Easy to set up, looks great, durability issues

Another thing I should mention is that it is pretty small - perfect for young kids. When I use it myself, I don't feel like it is big enough.

Overall I really do like this bottle, it is a GREAT concept and I am tempted to try out the Brita water bottles in the larger sizes (hopefully those wouldn't leak as much as this one?).

I received a set of Orfos lights as a gift off of my Amazon wish list.  I wanted to get a set because I am a bit obsessive about making myself visible during my commutes of up to ~45 minutes, often in the dark.  A friend described me as "lit up like Times Square on New Years Eve" ... and that was before I started using the Orfos lights.  The lights definitely make me even more visible.
I mostly like the lights.  I'm tempted to give them 4 stars but they definitely have some issues so I settled on 3.  They are quite bright on High, so bright that when I hold one to turn it on or off I cannot stand to look directly at the light.  The manufacturer advises against using the High intensity at night, with good reason.  Even on Low they are brighter than many other lights.  The light from the Orfos lights is somewhat directional, they definitely seem brighter from the front (or rear for the red light) than from the side, but they are MUCH more visible from the side than any other bicycle light I have ever seen.
I do not have the ability to measure light intensity but I made subjective comparisons of the Orfos lights to my Serfas Thunder Blast lights.  When viewed from directly in front of or directly behind the bike, the Orfos lights were more visible on Low than the Serfas lights on low. The Orfos lights on Medium were more visible than the Serfas lights on High.  The Serfas on High may have been slighty brighter than the Orfos on low, it was hard to be sure.  When viewed from the side, the Orfos lights on any setting are MUCH more visible than the Serfas lights on High.
The lights attach to the bike magnetically.  They come with extremely strong rare earth magnets that can be attached to the bike using zip ties.  When mounted vertically, as recommended by the manufacturer, the lights are held quite securely.  It is hard to imagine that a properly mounted light would come off the magnet while riding, even on rough roads.  They apparently can be mounted horizontally on a bicycle helmet and are reportedly secure but I have not tried that.  The one other Orfos user that I have met has his rear light mounted that way and has not had any problems.  The manufacturer recommends that they not be mounted horizontally on the bicycle itself because horizontal mounting is not as secure.
I have not had any of the problems reported by other users with spontaneous battery drain while not in use.
So, since I like the lights, why only 3 stars?  There are some issues.
Charging the lights is a SLOW process.  Using a multi-port USB charger rated at 12 W per port the lights took just over 2:50 to charge, much longer than the claimed 90 minutes.
The first set I received had run times nowhere near the claimed burn times and also had other problems; the company replaced them.  The replacement set performs considerably better than the original pair but burn times are still well below the claimed times except on Steady/High where my replacement set actually burns longer than the 1:15 claimed time.  Mine ran over 1:30.  My measured burn time for the lights starting from a full charge was generally about 50-60% of the claimed burn time except on Steady/High.  The manufacturer told me that they have experienced some problems with inconsistent battery performance in lights from recent production runs due to challenges related to use of an uncommon battery chemistry (LiFePO4).  It sounds like early adopters may have gotten better lights than those of us who acquired the lights later.
One of the replacements had some excess casing material that made it hard to insert the USB charging cable, but I was able to trim that off.  The switches on the batteries can be rather fussy, frequently making it hard to set the battery mode/intensity correctly. The lights are supposed to switch into Power Saver Mode for about 10-20 minutes when the battery is dying.  My replacement lights do make the switch, but they stay in Power Saver Mode for only about 5 minutes or less before they start generating dim random flashes.  The lights do not give any audible indication that they are failing. These manufacturing and performance issues raise concerns about quality control and longevity.
Mounting the magnets can be a challenge.  The magnets themselves are quite strong and once they are mounted the lights seem secure.  I have used the Orfos lights on 3 different bikes: an older road bike that I have set up for commuting, a newer road bike I ride for fun and a time trial bike.  The front light is supposed to be mounted on the head tube, but I was not able to mount it there on of ANY of the bikes I ride.  On ALL of my bikes the brake and/or derailleur cables would push the light off of its magnetic attachment during sharp turns.  My impression is that if my road bike stems were longer the cables would be far enough forward to avoid problems but my 80-90 mm stems just don't work with these lights.  Initially I attached the front light to my fork and that worked on two of the bikes but I was concerned that it would be easy to accidentally rotate the magnet to the inside, risking damage to both the wheel and the light. Ovalized/aero tapered fork blades make it hard to mount the light really securely.  Fortunately I was able to devise a handlebar mount that works well by using a K-Edge Go Big Camera Bicycle Mount. I found several of those mounts on sale for about $15, otherwise the cost would have been prohibitive.
Mounting the rear light on the seat post works OK if there is enough seat post exposed to secure the magnet.  Under-saddle bags for spares/... may interfere with the light depending on saddle height.  I have not found any way to mount the rear light on the seat post or seat tube on the time trial bike.  I have water bottle cages behind the seat on that bike and I was able to secure the magnet to the bottle cages but the zip ties do interfere somewhat with inserting/removing the water bottles.  Orfos needs to offer better mounting options for the magnets.
Bottom line: Knowing all of this would I buy the lights?  Probably.  They have some flaws and they are ridiculously expensive but they are quite bright and they definitely make me more visible.
Test method I used: I measured the burn times indoors with the lights mounted on one of the road bikes and because the lights generate a good bit of heat on the Medium and High settings I used a fan to create airflow which should simulate real world use reasonably well.
Ok.

reviewText:
Overall, for the price it's a pretty good tent - but please read the whole review before considering it. Great size, standing room, easy to set up. The "e-port" is in a good spot, though I'm not sure if I'll ever need it. The window flaps tuck into themselves to stow rather than using the little ties that most other tents use, I thought that was pretty cool.

I did find that one of the pole sleeves on mine hadn't been sown on all the way. There was about an inch of the sleeve that they'd missed with the thread - I'm sure after one camping trip the tension from the pole would have torn a good part of the sleeve off the tent, so I promptly sewed it up.

Biggest design flaw:

There are no flaps over the zippers for the doors/windows. So, hurray, there is nothing to jam up in the zipper, but come the rain you'll quickly realize why other tents have them. We ended up having a big puddle of water collect at the base of the door (inside the tent) on the very first night - we were lucky the ground was even so it didn't run over to our sleeping bags. The second night I used a spare tarp to cover the door, but that made getting in and out of the tent a huge hassle - definitely not a permanent solution.

For that reason I probably would not recommend this tent unless you're willing to modify it, or you are sure you won't be camping where it will rain.
summary: Zippers let in the rain / No rain flaps

reviewText: Velcro closure tabs are too short. Need to cut a lot of excess webbing off to make a better closure connection.  Lost one on the highway asa a result of short velcro tabs that didn't get enough grip area to hold.

Seems fairly solid and I was able to mount it on an ATV with 26 inch tires - barely.  If you have bigger wheels forget it.  With the slightly larger than stock tires, I found it more challenging to get super tight but not sure this would completely imobilize a wheel of any size unless there were spokes that the flanges could get deep between/inside.  If you really wanted to, you could still roll the quad on all four wheels as the clamp has just enough play to slip, but it would definitely slow you down a lot if you couldn't bust the locking mechanism which seems possible with a good size crowbar and a heavy hammer.  With an ATV two or more people could easily just pick up one corner of a quad and roll it on three wheels anyway so I knew going in this was certainly not the final line of defense but adds one more thing for a skumbag thief to work around without busting the bank.

Edit: I forgot that I had this on and drove it and the bar bent pretty easily before I realized it and it could be easily rolled around with it still attached in its mangled form but driving with it on would make a lot of noise.  Now it no longer locks but leave it on just so it looks more secure than it really is.
summary: One more deterrant but certainly not fool proof, especially on ATV.

reviewText: For the cost of this spotter scope I shouldn't have expected too much but its adequate for up to 150 yards on a range. I bought it because of the reviews and the cost. When zoomed in for close up on long range target, the FOV is very small and because of the light weight of the scope, its very susceptible to shutter in wind. The tripod is for tabletops and no more. If you want to use it while standing you'll either have to place it on a higher surface or use a longer tripod. I looked at the moon as the one reviewer showed and on a clear night viewing a full moon it does work well to see the outline of the craters but if your looking for a long range spotting scope for shooting, i would spend some more money and look for a better scope. Just my opinion, but I'm looking for another one myself.

reviewText:
There was a time when it was difficult to find quality backpacking pots that were strong, light, and durable over time. But that's just not the case now. I used the MSR Alpine 2 set since the mid 90's, so I think I can be pretty honest about the product.

For roughly $15 more, you can get a 1.4 liter titanium pot and pan (ie, the lid) from Snow Peak (http://www.amazon.com/Snow-Peak-Trek-1400-Titanium/dp/B000696D3I/ref=sr_1_1?s=sporting-goods&ie=UTF8&qid=1434218067&sr=1-1&keywords=snow+peak+1400). I've used the 1.4 liter to cook for 2 adults and 2 children with no problems, although it was about at maximum.

This product dates back to when high quality titanium was flimsy, expensive, and exotic. Now you can order it for very little price difference and get it sent via Prime.

If you want to lug heavy equipment into the wilderness, be my guest. While you're at it, perhaps strap a full size lawn chair to your back so you can sit on that instead of a flat rock or a bear canister. But if you're a reasonable person who wants to easily chop a pound of weight for barely any price difference, leave this where it belongs: in the history bin.
summary: there's no need to use this as a backpacker

reviewText: I think this would be best for using non-metal parts, like the polymer grip or stock of a gun that you want to clean. I tried using the picks like I would would with metal ones (thinking these would be super-hard thermoplastic), and sure enough, they all broke promptly. This would be good for cleaning out apertures (think HK MP5 sights), pmags, polymer stocks/rails (think Magpul), etc., but definitely not good for getting gunk out of the moving metal portions of your gun. Since I hardly ever have the need to clean any of those components with picks, I think this is something that you really won't need in your range bag. Tipton makes good steel picks -- just get those even though they're more expensive -- these will wear out, break, and end up costing more in the long run.
summary: Use for polymer components, NOT steel components!

I've used both these and Diamond's Strike on Box matches and here are a few comments.

Strike on Box matches are VERY reliable and will almost ALWAYS light after just one strike
Strike Anywhere matches sometimes take 4-5 strikes to light on the box and sometimes I can't even get these to light off the box on anything rough...even concrete

Box comes with dual-sided striking area and slide out box to easily access matches within

Match stems burn clean and when you blow them out there is minimal smoke and no glowing embers

Matches are loose in the box so you do not have to tear them from a matchbook

Box can withstand moisture well as we also keep it in the bathroom and it easily withstands the shower's moisture

These matches make a great "after using the restroom" match, but I prefer the Strike on Box match for this purpose

You should not spend more than $4 for a box of 250

3 stars for convenience, but minus 2 star for having to strike 4-5 times sometimes to get a light even on the box and not even being able to get a light off the box sometimes
summary: Okay Matches, but if you can get away with Diamond's Strike On Box matches I'd go with those because they're EASIER to light!!!

reviewText:
I have owned two Expilions and both have failed me; and the fundamental design flaws seem to be repeated. What is really disappointing is: both were fantastic lights at first, but neither made it past 18 months (first one failed after six months). The problems: poor mount, electrical system not built to last, silly instance on using their USB cable for charging.

Problem with first light that appears on all Expilions: cheap mount. They don't seem to have improved this at all; the light rattles around in the mount. My first light actually fell to the ground when the base of the mount failed (snapped). Well these things happen and other reviews noted the failure. The customer service at Cygolite was excellent and they quickly mailed me a new, better version of the Expilion, with a supposedly improved mount. And in all fairness the new mount didn't "fail" exactly.

The new light was better, stronger, faster. But the mount was still lame. I had to super glue it to stop it from swiveling since no amount of screwing it down prevented this. The swivel is an intended benefit so you can angel the light when you turn, but if it swivels on its own that's no good. But the super glue worked and I didn't care, even though it rattled in its mount (again). Thats annoying and can't be good for the light.

Then the killer: electrical failure at 18 months. At first the battery would die quickly so I figured it was time for a new battery. Not unreasonable after a year of almost daily use. But after ordering a new battery from Cygolite and installing it, it turns out that after the four or five hours of charging: still dead in 30 minutes. I get the low battery warning, and the light starts to fade soon after. I commute to work in the dark every day... that simply won't do.

A final annoyance: they say that you have to use THEIR USB cable to charge the light. I obeyed them, but this is a major hassle for a commuter. I would like to be able to use any USB cable, at any time in the home or office to charge it. The "U" in USB stands for "Universal". The coolness of USB charging goes out the window if you make me use your cable.

As I said their customer service is great, so if I call them they might replace this light too, but sorry Cygolite. I wanted to love you. I really did for a time. But... I've been hurt before. I don't want to be hurt again... and by that I mean by crashing into something in the dark. I'm going to give the NiteRider a whirl.

In theory the Dock Demon is a good idea, and at first it feels like a great little combo for the price.  The problem is the reel on the spincast models (in other words, a closed reel).  I bought one just to do indoor practice casting this winter, and as it turns out, the cat loves chasing the practice lure (it has no hooks) and he gets some exercise, so we both enjoy it.  That was only a few weeks ago and unfortunately, I'm now on my third Dock Demon.  The first one lasted a week with very light indoor use (maybe 30 - 40 practice casts) before the thumb button mechanism stuck in the pressed position so it couldn't be reeled in.  It's possible I could have taken it apart, messed with it, and gotten it working again for a while, but since it was so new I just returned it and got a new one.  The second one then lasted TWO weeks before the reel mechanism jammed and would not reel in for some reason, but that time the problem did not involve the thumb button.  I decided to give it one more try and returned the second one and exchanged it for a new one.  The third one is still just a few days old so we'll see how long it lasts.  Either way there's no way the first two should have failed so soon.  Other than the failure rate on the spincast reel, it's not a bad little combo, especially for the price. Btw, you can buy the Dock Demon Spincast shown in the ad above for $9.95 all day long at a certain national big box store chain if you have that option, and the Deluxe Dock Demon (open reel, cork handle, and a 6" longer rod) for $16.95. That will make it a bit quicker and more convenient when it jams and you have to return it (keep your receipt).
summary: In theory the Dock Demon is a good idea, and at first it feels like a ...

reviewText: Came in good time and packaged well. Good quality and would buy again

This bike rack has its ups & downs.  I drive a 4 door sedan & it was super easy to install & uninstall & my bike sat on it perfectly, didn't shake or move.  Super sturdy.  It comes with a drawstring bag for storage which I was super excited about.

However, the straps are partly stretchy which I personally did not like.  I worried that they might wear out as I'm pretty tough on everything.  Their durability is concern not fact, I returned this rack for a different one bc I was concerned. And I have small hands, so the pins that lock the arms in place were difficult & painful for me when storing the rack.

Overall this rack is wonderful but not perfect for me.

The quality of this item is very good. The finish is clean. The reason for the 4 star instead of 5 star was because they used a poor quality mounting screw. I went out and purchased 2, 8/32X11/4 inch hex screws to make them perfect
works great, don't over tighten or else handle might bend but you shouldn't over tighten anyways.
Fits good, looks good, I din't know why with all the pockets it has that they have two smaller pocket flaps on the breast pockets, but no pockets.

There is not much to athletic tape, just fabric and adhesive. In this case, the fabric is nicely balanced between thin and flexible and tight and strong. The adhesive is slightly less thick than with Ace brand, which is nice. It does not have the tendency to push through the fabric under hard use and stick to other surfaces. All around, this is my personal standby. Oh, and the color is rather nice for those who care.
summary: Good balanced tape, slight flex, limited adhesive transfer.

reviewText: It's a great net--assembles easily, is fine when left outside in the summer weather.  The soccer ball isn't an actual soccer ball--it's an inflatable rubber ball imprinted to look like a soccer ball.  It loses air quickly and the dog popped it within a few days.  Even so, I'd buy this set again for the net.
As expected.
It is a target.

Purchased for work in rehab setting, they breathe well and not heavy. Love Hanes undergarments so gave the Polo a chance and really like the feel and color of the shirts. Can wear outside of work if need be since materials feel really good on skin, not a big Polo shirt buyer but these definitely are working great for me.

reviewText: Good knife for the price.
The best firesteel money can by. If Grils uses it, it must be the best.

This is a very good chuck made of solid and heavy brass. It works well on Presta valves (as well as Schraders with the supplied screw on adapter). However, as other reviewers have noted, the fit can be very tight and you have to take care when pulling it off. I have just purchased a Topeak Smarthead chuck which has a much smoother removal action (it has a clamping lever which holds and releases the valve) and seals just as well as the brass chuck when on the valve.
For the money it good. Don't expect high end performance.
Worked perfect
works good on my crossbow

The sizing is odd. I wear size 11 shoes so I was between sizes. I ended up getting two pairs, one larger and one smaller size. They both fit. I use the tighter ones for bike shoes, and the others for walking or running. The seams aren't perfectly waterproof, but they work well in light rain. With heavy rain, water will drip down your leg into the sock. They really are breathable! Overall great sock!

i like this. works really cool on my samsung SIII - only reason it did not get the 5th star is because it did not fit very well on my Specialized Transition Pro Tri Bike. it has an aero shaped frame and this little device caters more to a round tube frame. the rubber band clamp would not wrap around because of this. and also, again, because of the shape of my Tri bike, i was not able to install the crank sensor and spoke sensor with the supplied rubber clamps. i had to makeshift some stuff with zip ties. this has nothing to do with how this unit functined though - it works great. i just wish i had more options when mounting.

These pants are high quality. The material seems durable and well made. There are many great things about them with just a couple complaints.

I am 6' and about 170lbs with a 32" waist. The fit is okay for the most part. What I expect though in a pair of compression tights is a snug fit all the way around. For me, these fit snug around my calfs,thighs, and my waist. They were not tight around my knees down to just above my calfs and they also lacked some support leaving me to require underwear under the tights. I have a pair of 2XU tights that are much tighter and offer more support overall. Granted, the 2XU are more than double the price. I believe if X31 offered a wider size range that they could cater the fit a little more. Offering tall sizes would be a big help.

Some of the great things about these are as follows:
They feel like a quality material and build
The reflective stripes are very bright, look cool, and offer safety
Zippers at the ankles make putting them on and taking them off very easy

I was sent these pants at a discount so I could test them out and give my honest feedback in this review.
Work great  Get the job done
Wish it was a little bigger but otherwise I like it.

It was fairly easy to install, but I had to work around the shifter and brake cables.  At 2.4 oz it was a little more weight than I wanted, but the 1/10 of a MPH I'll lose isn't going to make that much difference in my life. Very well made.  I feel confident that whatever I put on it will not be going anywhere.  My bar is 31.8 so I didn't have to mess with the spacers.  I'll buy it again.

reviewText: I've only used them a few times so far and they seem well padded and work well with my boxing gloves. I went with the small per the measurements and as indicated in prior reviews the finger holes are a little tight. Had I gone with the M the glove itself would have been too big. Hoping they will loosen up a bit after use. I'll update my review after I get some more use out of them.
summary: Good but finger holes are a little tight after going with measurements.

reviewText: These are fantastic cuffs.  You can't beat the performance for this price.  If you already have a pair of hinged cuffs and simply need a more flexible pair to use for other duties, the Model 100 should be at the top of your list.

Got this today.  I'm not really the bracelet type of guy, but it fits well (if you have any size to you at all, get the larger size).  I will put this on when I go to the woods (camping/fishing/hunting).  I might consider everyday wear.  Fits well, I almost got the smaller size, but glad I didn't.  I don't have huge forearms either.  All and all, this is a pretty cool product and I do recommend it.
summary: A Cool Product, you should just get it.

reviewText: Been using these for a few months. I love how adjustable they are, but I have to admit that I'm having trouble getting them to stay securely on my handlebars, but I think it's more of a problem with my bars than it is the aero bars. I have wrapped silicone wrap between my bars and the aero bars and it's helping to keep them from shifting.

I really like this knife. The size is very close to my Delica, which is my ideal size. I have large hands but don't care for many big folders.

It fits and feels good in my hands. I like the new G10 versus the one on my AUS8 American Lawman.

2 small nit picks though. The grind is not sharpened all the way to the little sharpening choil/notch. Also I wish the blade was a little wider. I bought the Code 4 and the blade is so much bigger but costs $10 less. I know it's because of the DLC coating and G10 but I wished I was getting a little more steel for the price. Other than that, it's a really wonderful knife.
I like the knife but the sheath is a bit funky but ok. I would buy again.

I purchased this product mainly for long road runs (for me that's anything over five miles) and for trail running.  Last year I ran the Xterra Table Rock 15K and carried my water bladder in an old WalMart backpack.  I've done this before but that race made it apparent I needed to make some changes.  I have not used the Rogue yet for trail runs but have used it on a couple 4 - 5 mile road runs.  So far it completely meets expectations.  I like the baffle in the water bladder which reduces sloshing.  The pack "carries" well and after the first half mile or so, I don't really notice it on my back any more.  I'll try to post an update after I've used it for trail runs and cycling.
summary: Excellent solution for hands-free hydration on runs

reviewText:
They seem strange at first because they don't actually have a thumbhole.  You quickly see the advantage though, as your thumb is completely unrestricted for grabbing.

Size selection seems to be really important -- for both my husband (very large hands) and 17 year old son (fairly average men's hands), the large size pinches on the outside near the thumb.  My husband assumed he just needed the XL size, but when it did the same for my son too, it seemed a bit off.  Marked it down a star for that.

It seems to have more padding than the standard MMA gloves, as there is a lot thicker padding in the knuckles than a gel-padded MMA glove.

Good wrist support.  Nice, wide straps.  Easy to put on and off.  It has double velcro, so there is a small amount on the inside of the wrist, and a larger velcro area on the outside of the wrist.

The fingers are shorter on the inside and longer on the outside  so there is really good coverage as you are punching, and plenty of room for grabbing on the inside.

The increased padding is nice for a heavybag or a BOB.
good product except hard to operate air valves

Some review mentioned that S-bend is not anatomically natural and might strain your wrist. To me, however, S-bend is very comfortable. I feel that S-bend let me exert higher power on pedaling than J-bend. One issue: the arm pads are too wide for me.

Ever think what you would do when your key fails to insert and/or lock fails to unlock? This happened to me, the key would insert only 1/4th of the way. Spent some time jiggling the key to no avail. Tapping the sides with a hammer failed too. Now I have a chain which won't unlock. Aaarrrrgh!!!!!

Customer Service
- 800 number is no longer in service
- Online ticket gets response in 4 days
- Start complaining and it seems your ticket gets escalated quickly
- Todson said to get a locksmith to cut the chain off the lock. Baloney, like their ads state the chain is impervious to bolt cutters [42", 4000 lb]. Tried one and it didn't even put a nick on the chain. Plasma cutter did the job.
- Todson did offer a $100 reimbursement for expenses paid and a new chain. Will update later on this.
summary: Cheap locking mechanism; Superman strong chain

reviewText: Useful apparatus and very good for the price but I think that should come with the pump.
Great quality, comfortable, sharp looking, but I like my thumb higher on the pistol for better control. 4 stars for this.

Pros:
Cheap. As the title suggests I wasn't looking to spend a lot on a tent. I also wanted a tent with enough room to stand up in.
Roomy. This tent allowed me to fit a full sized inflatable mattress, as well as a large mountain bike on its side. Lots of space. The only "downside" was that the tent is so tall I have to stand up to turn the lantern on or off if i choose to hang it from the top center position (i am 5'8" and the lantern hanging in the center had about 2 inches of clearance over my head).
Attached photo shows a full sized mattress with a mummy sleeping bag, for scale.
Tent poles feel heavy and sturdy. It is not the easiest to set this tent up and disassemble it alone but it's not hard, either. The rainfly goes up easiest if you clip one end in before trying to manouver it over the tent.

Cons:
As another review mentioned the door zipper is a bit of an oddity in that there are 2 separate zippers, one for the bottom and one for the rest of the door. It's a minor inconvenience but I would have preferred one motion.
There was no stakes additional guy lines for the sides of the rainfly, although there are loops on the bottom of the rainfly that suggest that is its use. I'll be buying more stakes/cord to fix that going forward, I was able to use plastic bundling from firewood to imitate a cord and keep the rainfly from pressing against the inside of my tent during 2 nights of light rain.
As seen in the stock photo, the screen part of the door only zips down from the top 25% or so of the door so you will have to open the door to get better ventilation. There are no other adjustable windows but there are other mesh areas for some ventilation.

Minor issues, would buy again.
summary: Good budget tent for car camping

reviewText: Not sure it killed all bugs but I had great tomatoes this year

These are pretty nice toe clips. They are plastic and flexible. I don't foresee these breaking or snapping from normal usage. The straps are of good quality, although some instructions on the best way to rout them would have been helpful.

The lack of instructions is why I took off a star. It's annoying to have to guess which is the right way to thread the straps.

I installed these on some crummy old plastic pedals. I had to drill holes in the pedals to attach the clips. They fit snugly and securely with the included screws and lock nuts.

The clips have horizontal slots which accommodate various pedal hole placement as well as clip placement.

I would say size 9 men's shoe would be the cutoff for the small size as the clips are indeed small. An average sized man would probably need a medium or even large size. I have size 8 feet and the small size fits me well when wearing vans style slip on shoes. I would need a medium if I wore larger style shoes.

The small size is only $4. Just go for it. they improve your pedaling efficiency enormously.

Protip: practice getting in and out of these somewhere where no one can see you fall on your side at 1 mph.
summary: Decent set of toe clilps. Great value.

reviewText: If you take this for its name, a luge, you won't be disappointed, as it does well on icy or hard-packed snow surfaces. Also, it is best suited to smaller body styles, as the seating area is quite small.

I was using a previous rack that ended up scrapping my high priced mountain bikes. I was looking for a hitch style or roof style but they are very expensive, especially when both of my cars do not have hitches. It doesn't help that my Ford Taurus has a weak trunk for some reason and the Thule racks were not rated well for my car. I was ready to spend over 250 dollars for a quality trunk rack when I came across this one. It had all the features I was looking for, minus the wire style attachment system of the Thule and the locking system that can detour theft.

Despite that, for the money, this rack is awesome. It can be a bit tedious to mount but it is very stable. I took two Trek 29er MTBs and a road bike across the county with no problems and no bike damage thanks to the anti sway strap system. Be sure to invest in some devices that lock the wheels and fork in place and you will have a decent setup at an exceptional value.

reviewText: Fits the same as all their other shirts.

Light output is nice and bright. The one thing I wish was different though is the LED usage when you collapse it down. As you collapse it less light comes out, but all the LED's remain in use. If the lower LED's would turn off as the unit was collapsed the batteries would last MUCH longer. I bought this for my response 'go bag'. As a volunteer member of a disaster response team having devices that will consume less power is ideal. It would be useful if there was a unit like this that was also rechargeable with a USB (solar) battery pack. That is very use case specific though so I did not rate it lower for that. Wouldn't really recommend for gentle yoga where you aren't going to working up a sweat (unless you spray it down).

The only thing is that they do wear pretty quickly if you are doing a lot of hot yoga and needing to wash the mat a lot (we always hang to dry). Definitely recommend spraying down with a hose versus placing in the washer.

connected to my Tikka T3 .270 WSM AFTER (sling attachment pins fit in this bipods sling mount) attaching the : TipTop EZ Rifle Bipod 13.5" - 23": Sling Stud Mount, Extendable, Folding, with Sling-attached Hole PN:S3-34661

These pads fit really well, and stay in place better than any I've used, though I have to admit I've only ever used mid to low end pads (six or seven varieties though).  Pretty firm surface, but for some reason it's not a problem at all, in fact I love it for punches, you get a good pop.  The handle is really thick and firm, which makes a huge difference, and the curve is excellent and my hands fall in place just right, so my forearms don't get so fatigued and cramped. Not the lightest pads I've used, but not bad.  Compact size and shape are great for punches, but may take a little getting used to for knees and kicks, though I got the hang of it!  The arm bands aren't riveted like many of the other pads, especially the high end stuff, so this may be the weak point, but it also gives a nice round wrap around the forearms and they feel very attached and easy to maneuver as a result.  If they last a year I'll feel it was a good deal, and maybe move up to some Fairtex at that point.
summary: and stay in place better than any I've used

My three and a half year old loves his new 'big boy bike'! I would have waited to gift him this until he was four, but grandma came to town and just had to spoil him. He's tall for his age but can only reach the ground with his tippy toes so we had to keep the training wheels on. I wish the training wheels were rubber instead of hard plastic, because they make a lot of noise. The reflectors it came with don't stay in place on the frame, even though they are tightened properly. And like other reviewers have mentioned, this bike is quite heavy. That said, this bike is well made and my kid loves it. He used his balance bike a lot, so the transition to a pedal bike was quite smooth. The only thing I am missing is one of those foam frame pads for on the handle bars. I would pay extra for one, but can't find one. I worry that once we take the training wheels off he would fall with his teeth on the bar, so I'd like to pad it. Also, living in a rainy climate it would be nice to be able to purchase a mud flap type thingy for this bike, but that's also not available. Something to consider for Diamondback.
summary: Great bike, nice quality, my son loves it. Wish more accessories were available.

reviewText: good BB, still using it today 10-6-15
Second routine I've gotten for the wife.  She seems to like it as much as the XTFMaxx series
Good quality - my daughter loves it

Right to it...

+++++++++++++++++++++
+ The Pros
+++++++++++++++++++++

[+ QUIET OPERATION]: We have ours setup between our bed and the wall, and the gap is very small having only enough room to get on the bike (so it's tight). I have no problem falling asleep while my Wife uses the bike.
[+ EASY SETUP]: It took me about 2 hours to put it together myself. All the directions were straightforward.
[+ COMFORTABLE SEAT]: The padding is thick and firm. It will last a good long time and extended use is not problem.
[+ SPACE FOR LAPTOP/TABLET ON TOP OF CONSOLE]: The top of the console has a holder for things like books and magazines. My Wife puts our Netbook on there to watch videos and shows and it stays in place no problem.
[+ NECESSARY ASSEMBLY TOOLS INCLUDED]: Though Nautilus says all necessary tools are included and nothing else needed...You really do need some kind of cutting tool (like a razor knife) to cut through the tape and plastic. Other than that everything required is indeed included.
[+ CLEAR INSTRUCTIONS]: The included booklet had lettered/numbered diagrams that made putting everything together pretty straightforward. All the tools and nuts and bolts were also packaged together in a way to make it easy to find and know what's what and where.
[+ DOESN'T REQUIRE A LOT OF SPACE]: We live in a condo and space is tight. We decided to put the bike in our bedroom, between our bed and the wall. The bike is almost flush against the wall on one side and the other side there's only about 2ft of space to get on/off the bike. No problem.

-------------------------------------
- The Cons
-------------------------------------

[- VERY HEAVY]: Usually with equipment like this, heavy weight is indicative of quality (and it is, this bike is very solid) but it can also be a negative as the small height adjustment knob on the bottom of the bike wasn't just broken during shipping but was pretty much shattered.
[- A BIT TIGHT FOR TALL FOLKS]: My wife is 5'11" and even with the seat all the way back she said her knees still feel a bit cramped. It's not too bad though as she's still able to use the bike and get the workout she wants out of it.

=====================
Conclusion
=====================

This is a good, solid bike and requires little space and performs well. We both work and have a young child so getting out to the gym isn't easy. We're happy about having this product and would recommend it.

I am a yoga teacher and a practitioner and I used yoga mats all the time.  Gaiam is a good provider of yoga gear and I was looking forward to receiving  this may.  It is perfect for women because of the color and it has a lovely flower design.  Mat is also very light and it can be carries easily if one is on the go a lot. In fact, mat is so light that one does not need a yoga mat or yoga strap to carry it.

I used the mat during my yoga class at the gym that has wood flooring.  I must say that mat did not grip the floor too well.  It was sliding to easily.  However, once practitioner is on the mat's top surface, it prevents any slippage.  Because mat is so thin, I would not recommend it to anyone with bad/weak knees.  There is not enough cushioning on the mat to make it easy for the poses where one has to be on her knees.  I have not tried using this mat on top of another mat, but for anyone practicing hot yoga this may be an option of placing this thin mat on top of the thicker one.  That would avoid having to use towels and hoepfully once could still have a firm grip during a very sweaty practice.

I have used similar mat from Gaiam that is much thicker and heavier and I must say that personally I prefer a thicker mat for my practice.  It may be heavier ot practice but it has a better grip once it its on the floor.
