This is a pretty good little loader for the money.  It isn't a dillon, but for a third of the price of a dillon, it works pretty well.  Setup isn't too bad (although the instructions are pretty terrible).  Getting it fine tuned and adjusted is pretty easy (especially if you have some loading experience).  A couple of things to watch though.  First, make sure you have a powder scale or something similar to help you set your powder charge as the chart lee provides is NOT accurate on any of the powders we have used. Second, be prepared to adjust it on a semi regular basis. Third, always make sure you hear it click into its station before you seat the primer (refer back to step two if it doesn't click in), failure to do so could cause the primer to be crushed rather than seated causing it to detonate (which if you are using CCI, Remington, or Winchester primers this will simply wake you up and get your attention but if you are using federal or wolf primers, it can ruin your whole day and then some as these two brands can cascade fire off each other).  Fourth stick with CCI, Remington, or Winchester primers due to #3.

In the end, I like the loader.  It isn't a dillon but that's like saying a ford isn't a Cadillac.  They both get you there, but one is more luxurious than the other.  One is also far more expensive than the other.  For the price of one dillon, I can own three of the Lee's in various calibers.

Properly setup and adjusted, it will crank out a lot of cartridges.  And as long as you keep it adjusted correctly, it will keep cranking out the cartridges.

reviewText:
Had this about two weeks.  It's nice and sturdy, and I really like the removable legs - you can use it with or without the legs, so if you have a really tall pot, you can still reach into it.
When the stove arrived, I tried it out at home before heading to the bay to cook up our crab catch.  I tried to light it and got really frustrated.  Then I read the instructions about turning the gas valve on slowly and letting the propane fill the gas line. There is a safety valve that shuts the gas off if it's turned on too high.  I still had trouble lighting it at the dock, too, so it is a little touchy.
Once it's lit, though, I brought 5 gallons of water to a rolling boil in about 20 minutes on the 60K BTU burner.  The 30K BTU burner hadn't gotten rolling, but had little bubbles on the bottom of the pot. I'm just going to have to get a bigger pot and cook the crabs all on one burner.
I didn't have the wind screen on the stove at the dock, and the breeze blew the flame out a couple times. Next time I'll bring it along to keep the flame from going out.
summary: Nice stove but READ the instructions!

I've used four different pull up bars over the years, all of them door-mounted. The door mounts work okay, but you have to bend your knees to clear the floor and they always mess up my door frames. This is the first ceiling-mounted pull up bar I've tried. It is 48" on center, so it was easy to mount to my 24" joists, despite the fact that my house is over 100 years old. Installation took about 2 hours, but mostly because I had trouble locating my joists without a stud finder. Once it was up, it was solidly installed, so I didn't have to worry about it coming loose during the middle of a set. It is a bit intrusive in my guest bedroom, so I would recommend taking that into consideration when thinking about using this. The nice thing about a door mount is I can remove it when I'm done. With this, it is up there for good. It has a nice width so you can do wide pull ups, and the best thing is that I don't have to bend my knees anymore when doing pull ups. My only real complaint is that I think the bar is a little too thin for my hands and would prefer if it was a little thicker. I got around this by wrapping tennis grip around the bar.
summary: A bit obtrusive but works much better than a door-mounted bar.

This is a handy item for camping, or peace of mind in an emergency, or carrying in a car.  It provides a bright lamp and AM/FM/weather radio in a compact package that can be powered without batteries simply by turning a crank.  The instructions say that a minute of winding allows six minutes of light. I didn't sit there with a stopwatch but it seemed reasonably accurate, and turning the crank is easy enough.  Sure, it gets tedious after a while; ten minutes of cranking takes some patience.  But it's a reasonable tradeoff for an hour of light and/or radio without batteries or access to electricity, and if all you need is five minutes of light, it's a snap.  The light produced is quite bright, has a high and low setting, and can illuminate a small room to allow cooking or reading.  The radio tuner is digital, and I got decent reception although there's no external antenna.

The problem I had was in trying to use the device to charge other devices through the USB port.  I tried to charge an ipod without success, and then tried to charge a cell phone (a Droid), also without success; neither would show that they were being charged at all.  Perhaps there are some devices that this will actually charge, but apparently not many.  Otherwise, no complaints, although if I were shopping for something like this I'd look around to see if there's one that has a solar charger--it would offer similar no-battery convenience without all the cranking.
summary: Works Well, except for USB Charging

reviewText:
I work in an open office environment where everyone can see you pick your nose.  I don't pick my nose, just in case you're wondering.  I also sit directly under a skylight which makes computing pretty much impossible because of the overhead glare and the incessent hum of the office A/C funneled down through that skylight.  This clamps onto my monitor stand and effectively blocks some of the noise and makes the light situation so much better.  In case of a fire, I can sit quite comfortably under the sprinkler system and remain dry.

The one drawback that I can find is that there needs to be just one more joint near the canopy to tilt it a little more.  The clamp is pretty secure and opens quite wide.

The canopy is made of fabric and aluminum tubing with plastic joints and clamps.  Overall, it doesn't feel flimsy and it's built quite nice.
summary: Works pretty well as cube canopy at work.

reviewText: Its small but super compact so its perfect for dispersed camping. It was all I could afford and I'm, happy with it so far.

No instructions were provided.  After spending a bit of time to understand the device, I quickly figured out how to make all of them light up and am happy with the product.  Read on...

All units have a piece of paper in the battery case that needs to be removed.

Once I removed them all seemed to still not work!  Here is the deal....they are motion activated.

Put them on the valve stem, ride,  and they will light up.

6/10 worked.  Not great quality, but not bad either for 10 bucks.
summary: Work well once you know how they work!

reviewText:
As a petite female, I've been struggling to find a backpack that has a waist belt, was larger than a regular backpack, but small enough to be used for travelling, doesn't break the bank, fits well, and looks normal enough to be used in everyday life. This backpack is the closest I've come to finding a match. I will note that my fiance, who is 6' 3" was able to adjust this bag to fit him as well, so I expect this will work for a wide variety of users.

The zippers feel sturdy, the buckles/compression straps are easy to adjust. I also like the compression straps on the bottom of the bag, which could be used to hold a sleeping pad or something similar in a pinch. The organizational pocket in the middle compartment is quite functional. Surprisingly, even though this bag is geared towards males, I actually thought the straps were a bit skinnier than the Sonju bag I received, a plus in my book as it makes this bag more usable for females. I love that the interior fabric is in a contrasting color on the darker colored bags. The pocket on the waist belt is nicely sized and can fit a phone or a small snack - I also appreciate that the waist belt can be hidden away so desired. I found that despite stuffing the pockets full, this bag doesn't suffer from something other packs do - where if you stuff one pocket full, it encroaches upon the space in the neighboring pocket... this backpack seems to have been designed well enough that that's not a problem! The zippered pockets behind the water bottle pockets are super useful and one of my favorite parts of this bag.

As for cons...the "barrier" pocket for sunglasses is quite difficult to open one-handed. The top handle is flimsy, but on this bag there's another handle anyway so not a big deal. I wish that the vented spongey material on the straps extended farther down, because the bottom of these straps are stiff, probably to make them more sturdy, but it is a bit uncomfortable. I don't find this bag particularly water-resistant; I had my phone in the top "barrier" pocket and there were several raindrops on the phone screen when I took it out to check the time 5 minutes after it had started raining. I wish the front pocket had an organizational unit as well and that both sides of the waist belt had a zipper pouch. I've had this bag for a little over half a year, and the mesh on the waterbottle pocket started to fray a bit...patched up with some clear nail polish, but I much preferred the sturdier water bottle pockets on the 'Superior' pack. I don't particularly like the color choices - I'd love an all gray or the gray/green combo that's offered on the female version of this bag.

Overall, this is a good quality bag if you're looking for something larger than the average backpack, fairly comfortable, and moderately priced.
summary: Not perfect, but pretty close! Great for those looking for something between a hiking pack and regular backpack

The backboard is very stiff, and produces some interesting deflections.  My daughter and I love this though.  The hoop material is incredibly strong.

reviewText:
I have stated before; I am an old fan of Cold Steel products. Unfortunately, over the years I have watched their QC go to crap. Sometimes they hit the mark, other times they dont. This one they came close to hitting the mark. As with most tomahawks and battle axes from CS, the heads are loose. No big deal, you can tighten them up a number of ways. My only issue this time around was the edge. It was as sharp as a butter knife. I understand utilitarian edge, but this was just plain poorly sharpened. Bad QC.

I am keeping it regardless. I know how to properly sharpen an axe.

BTW- this is a weapon. I would avoid using it for heavy utilitarian purposes. If you order one, youll see why.
summary: Cold Steel- need better QC- still nice

reviewText:
Gloves were surprisingly warm. And snug. But a good snug. I thought it was too small but it worked out. I actually really like these gloves and they keep me warm. I used them for skiing/snowboarding in below zero temperatures (Fahrenheit) and it kept me reasonably warm, believe it or not. They aren't waterproof but they're warm.

My only gripe with these gloves is the grips and the touchscreen sections. The rubbery grips on the fingertips lasted about a few days. After one wash, I think I only had a partial section of one finger left on each glove. After the 2nd wash, all the grips were essentially gone. And the touchscreen section only works sometimes. But it's better than my other gloves that don't work at all. All in all, I'm considering buying a new pair and returning these since I loved them when they were new. Or I may just keep these and deal with the missing grips. :/
summary: Snug and warm, but rubber grips fall off after 1-2 washes.

Rather then return it I thought i will try this one, it's SURE to fit the bore!  Well that's true alright...but the tip is 5 x 40 and all my cleaning attachments are 8/32...so, rather then return it, or buy all new attachments...I just got a 5x40 to 8/32 adapter 9image) and loctited this in place, on the end of this rod. I should have paid more attention to what i was buying, but, at least now I might have something I can use in a .22 rifle bore.
summary: Beware!  This rod uses 5x40 threads on the end, most of your attachments are probably 8/32 so - you'll need an adapter

Super Microfiber Towels.  These are Great for Wicking the Sweat, but Fold Down to Nothing Flat.  They Take Up No Room in a Backpack or Gym Bag.  Theyre Non-Slip, Making Them Safer & Come in a Myriad of Colors & Sizes.  You'll Receive a Set of Two Super Absorbent Microfiber Towels.

My Gym Charges $1.00 Rental for Each Towel.  That Doesnt Sound Like Much, But When You Go Often and Use a Couple Towels, It Adds Up.  I Carry a Tiny Spray Bottle of Disinfectant with me & Give a Quick Spray to the Machines, Before I Climb On.  Yes, Im One Of Those People That Grab a Couple of Wipes, When I Go Into the Grocery Store or Wal-Mart & Give the Basket a Good Quick Wipe.  I Hate the Idea of Germs Everywhere & I Dont Like Climbing on a Sweaty Machine.  When I Get Off the Machines, I Always Wipe it Off For the Next Person.  Everyone Should Do That, but That Doesnt Happen.  So, One of These Towels will Be Marked & Reserved as my Gym, Sweat Towel to Use on the Machines.  The Other Towel Im Using for MY Sweat Towel and that One Wont be Marked  That Way I Dont Get Them Mixed Up.  I Also Bring My Own Locker Room Towel In With Me.  By Taking My Own Towels, I Save about $10 or So a Week & Over Time It Adds Up.  Then, Being Cheap (Ahem Frugal) I Bring Plenty of My Own Water, (Sometimes with Lemon or Lime in It) so I can Avoid the Temptation of the Overpriced Juice Bar.  Its Like the Ice Cream Truck.  When Youre Hot, you Put Out The Money, Then Later You Think, How Much Did I Pay For That Thing?  I Could Have Bought a Whole Box of Them For That, at the Store.  It Pays to Plan Ahead & These Little Towels Can Be Both A Convenience and a Money Saver in the Long Run.

Microfiber Towels Wash Up Really Easy, but I Usually Wash My Microfiber Towels Separate From the Rest of the Wash.  I Use Microfiber Towels for Cleaning & Polishing My Vehicles Too.  Of Course You Have to Keep Them Separate.  You Cant Use the Towels on Your Face That Youre Using on Your Truck or for Disinfectant.  I Make sure my Vehicle Microfiber Towels are all Red & Yellow, so I Dont Get Them Mixed Up With the Others.  If you Use Some for Dusting & Different Uses, I Suggest Going with Different Colors.  There are Also Different Grades of Micro Fiber Towels.  Some Have More Fiber To Them & Some are Finer.  It Depends on What Youre Wanting to Use it For.  This Grade of Microfiber Towel is Just Right for a Certain Amount of Absorbency & a Little Bit of Exfoliation.  Its Really Good For the arms & Legs or Wiping the Sweat From Your Face.

A few months ago these goggles were priced at $59.00, which I thought would be a fair price if they were well-made. But I was offered a pair for FREE in exchange for a fair and balanced review. It took me 6 weeks to get to that review as in rainy Washington state we haven't had much sun or use for goggles. Now that the snow is in our mountains and weve getting some sunshine, Ive tested them as has my pilot-in-training son. We both give these goggles a high rating. But we need to test them under skiing conditions to come up with a possible 5-star rating.

I have to wear my regular glasses and these goggles accommodate them well without pressing my glasses against my head. I also noticed that they are usable in less-than-direct sunlight, not too dark. The lenses are also resistant to fogging up, with just touches of fog under quick changes in temperature and humidity. But the lenses clean easily  just use non-scratch material.

I also appreciate the handy yet tough carrying case along with a bag for protecting the goggles and even cleaning them. This is important because any polarized goggles are prone to scratching. As for looks,  when I wear these goggles, I don't know how I look to others. But when I look in my mirror, I think I look COOL, MAN!
summary: COOL, MAN! say these goggles when I wear them! Good value because --

I normally wear a size US 12 so my wife bought these so that they would be a little big and more comfy. They pretty tight, but they are extremely comfortable and well made.
Needs to be on a large knife in my opinion.  It's a little too large for my taste but very well made and some people prefer larger

the knife itself is great. i also have the izula 2 and sometimes prefer this one because of the blade size and shape. the coating does not hold as well as the izula 2, but still strong. a lot of people think this is a great knife to get if you want to try out esee knives but don't want to pay the price, but that isn't necessarily true because the blade is very different. my main problem is with the stock sheath(as noted on many other reviews). there is a loud rattle when the knife is sheathed, and the knife DOES dull if it scratches the sheath on the way out/in. the only way to prevent this is to pull the knife out straight so it doesn't scratch the side, but you will not always remember this when you are out camping or backpacking and need your knife immediately. i would personally recommend making or buying a kydex sheath (leather is good too). you can find some on ebay that will run you about $30 . you will also need to buy a tek lock or g clip if you want to mount the knife on your belt that will cost you about $10. so expect to pay near izula 2 money if you want a custom sheath (and you don't want to make it yourself).

all in all i think the knife is a good value, but i can confirm that in about 3 or 4 swipes against the side of the sheath the knife becomes noticeably dull, which may be a problem if you are in the field and don't have a sharpener.

My only complaint is that when the bottles are full it bounces a bit too much and feels like it's pulling me backwards. However I just turn it around so the bottles are in the front. This works much better and it is easier for access to the hydration bottles and the pouch in front which holds my gels/phone/etc. I did a half marathon race with this pack and it was too heavy for racing.  I would definitely recommend this product for long hikes/walks/or training runs, but not racing.
summary: Great quality pack and holds everything I need for long runs!

reviewText:
We used this tent only once so far, on a trip to Mount Rainier NP, and it worked great.  We saw at least a couple of these around the campground (Ohanapekosh).

Good things:
- Set up really was very quick.  Putting in the pegs is the most time consuming part.
- Once it was up it looked great and was roomy enough inside to easily fit four 39x84 rectangular sleeping bags.
- There are two mesh vents above two of the windows so you can get some ventilation with the windows closed.  That said, it would be nice to be able to close those if desired.
- Breaking the tent down was not particularly hard and after you do it once you understand how it works and future times should be faster.  The important part is that the frame arms need to be bent (the hinge is under the cloth joint cover so you may need to lift the cover to see what direction it bends) after telescoping them closed.  then you just try to keep it compact (we didn't bother with the ties that were included as they were thin and not helpful but if you brought some wider straps that would be useful) and stuff it in the case which was not that hard to do (can be done by one person but better with two).
- Easy to carry around/store when in the case.

A few things I didn't like:
-  It's too easy for the telescoping frame arms to collapse by pressing in the metal "bump" that pops out when extended.  Our toddler kept pushing it in (it's that easy to do) and collapsing part of the tent which then led the other arms to collapse too.
- Door is kind of unnecessarily large which requires a lot of zipping to open/close.  Horizontal zipping is more of a hassle too.
- Only two mesh pockets inside and a ring at the ceiling to hang a light from.  Would have liked a little more storage inside.
- The integrated rain fly does not cover the side windows as well but it probably won't leak as there is protective stitching/flap to keep rain out when the window is closed.

Bottom line is that we really enjoyed using this tent despite some concerns about the telescoping arms being easily collapsed due to the lack of a locking mechanism (a simple hole that you could put a pin through would suffice) for the four frame arms and recommend it highly.
summary: Works well enough and very convenient tent.

reviewText:
I purchased this bicycle basket a couple of months ago. I originally installed it on my bicycles rear rack. It did not sit flush on the rack because there was a raised lip at the rear of the rack and if tightened down it would deform the basket. I left it loosely installed, and then a few days later took a ride and it loosened and I lost some of the hardware. So it sat for a while. I finally  figured how to install the basket with a spacer between the basket and the rack and a couple extra nuts and bolts so it sits flush. It is a permanent installation and switching it to another rack would be a longer process.

The construction of the basket seems to be black powder coated metal, probably steel judging by the weight. The mounting hardware is also steel, with the cross brackets being black powder coated. The mesh part of the basket is easily deformed and once deformed it is difficult to bend it back to it's original shape. In fairness though should Basil have used a heavier mesh it would have made the basket much heavier.

I am satisfied with the basket and would recommend it to a friend as long as the friend had a rack with a flat surface to mount the basket to.
summary: A Tisket, a Tasket, another Bicycle Basket

Because the sizing is just off, It can ride up on longer rides.  The waist comes up kind of high. It doesn't go high enough to go beyond my belly button, but is short enough that it rides down. So I end up rolling it down, creating a rolled bunch at the waist and it's not the best.

Oh, yeah, it comes in a good box too.  Don't throw the box away, use it to store your paddle between matches.  Doing this prolongs the life of the paddle surfaces that tend to get scuffed up and lose their tackiness if you don't keep it protected.

I'm no professional by any means, but I've played lots of matches (for fun) over the years and it's easy to tell when you have a good surface on your paddle, and this has that!

This is a great all around watch, full of great features with easy to use settings, but I find that the backlight feature does not provide a lot of light, and it only reads clearly from certain angles.

The watch is chock full of features, including stopwatch (with lap), timer, and hourly chime. One feature you don't always see is that it has dual time readouts, which is useful for those who need to keep track of a second time zone. Setting the various functions will require reading the instructions the first time, but nothing is too difficult.

The watch is darker than the product page pictures, and is really quite sharp looking - I like the red accents. It is comfortable to wear, with a wider band than some.

There are two things that keep this from getting the highest rating. First, the display is angle dependent; from certain angles it just disappears. It is quite readable from the other angles. This means that you have to turn your wrist properly to see it clearly. The other thing I don't care for is the back lighting. It is "luminescence" instead of a more traditional lighting. The idea is that the entire back is lit, but is shows through only the letters - this results in less energy use. The light lasts about 3 seconds after you push the button. What it means in practice is that the back lighting is pretty dim. In daytime, if the watch is the shadows, the back light doesn't really do much at all. I would prefer a light that is at least three times brighter. It does show up in total darkness.

Summary: Nice looking with great features, but the backlight could use some work. Recommended if you can live with this.

Plenty of room for 2 bats plus a folding practice tee in the bat compartment, shoes in the shoe compartment (though it's a bit of a squeeze for a pair of size 11.5s), 3 mitts and 4 softballs in the main compartment with much room to spare. Bats and shoes intrude on the main compartment, so it does take some adjusting to get everything wedged in. No shoulder strap, but the carry handles are long enough to work. The outer material is medium-weight; I expect eventually there will be a tear or rub-through, but it's enough for a casual player like myself. Shoe compartment material is light; it would not surprise me if the cleats tear through that some day. Note that the fence hook is inside the bat compartment. Not pro quality or fashionable like the 2-bat backpacks everybody seems to have nowadays, but great for the price.

I got tired of trying to inflate the bike tires on my family's four bikes with my hand held portable pump and bought the Planet Bike 1002-3 ALX based on price and ratings.  I wasn't disappointed.
The hots:
1) "Love Handle" - two hand grips at just shy of a 90 degree angle comfortably fit the angle your hands are at when held in front of you pushing.  The handle is padded plastic that feels fine.

2) The fitting that latches onto the tire is plastic, but of beefy construction with a metal latch.  I find it gets great seal on all my bike tires no problem.

3) The gauge is a real treat for me.  It's got the various tire types color coded.  It was an education for me:  I realized I had been chronically under inflating my bike tires for years.  Inflating them to the right pressure was easy, quick, and precise.  It felt great biking on the correctly inflated tires.

4) Aluminum tube looks great and inspires confidence.

Nots?  Maybe all the plastic parts (handle, base, fittings) means it will not last as long.  At the rate I use a bike pump and how beefy all these parts feel to me I think this will last a long long time.

All in all - the bottom line is that I was able to inflate my tires with very little effort, and in very little time, with great precision.  This thing made inflating all those bike tires, if not an absolute pleasure, at least much less of a chore.
summary: An excellent ergonomic bike pump at a great price.

reviewText:
I am satisfied with the Hyskore vise that I mainly ordered to aid in the mounting of scopes. The vise is made of mostly sturdy metal, with some plastic mixed in mainly in the form of adjustment  knobs and the fire's feet.
Following the simple to comprehend instructions, complete with photos, I had this assembled in about 5 minutes. It just so happened that I had a brand new bolt action that I purchased the day before that needed a scope mounted onto it. I put the butt stock into the rear of the vise and clamped it down with the padded knobs. The fore stock went into the front V-shaped fork and using the adjustment knobs, I leveled the rifle. A center support is also there to support the middle of the rifle. There is an included magnetic bubble level that comes with the vise. After that, it was extremely easy to level the scope reticle properly.
This vise can also be used for cleaning and mechanical sighting in of an optic. The instructions state very clearly that a clamped and strapped down weapon should NOT be fired from this vise. The instructions do say that one can collapse the rear clamp and center support (they are on tubes and slide back and forth, depending on the length of your firearm) all the way forward to the front V rest and fire the gun. Then, while keeping the vise in place, one can clamp their gun in and adjust their optic's point of aim to the fund's point of impact after a 3 to 5 shot group is shot. That is the mechanical sighting in they are referring to in the product description. Just read the aforementioned instructions and you can't go wrong.
I think that most people would be satisfied with this gun vise and I have no problem recommending it other shooters and hunters.

I am on my second Kinzi insulated wide mouth thermos.  The first bottle I received leaked like crazy.  However, I was able to exchange with zero problems, and the turn around time was one day for me.  Because of the quality service and no fuss exchange, I didn't take off any stars.

This thermos is very similar to very highly rated Hydro Flask, the construction and bottle top are nearly identical.  In fact the bottle lids are compatible.  This bottle keeps my water cold for many hours even in the hot.  At some point I will do a head to head with my Hydro Flask to see which bottle keeps my beverage coldest for longer.  I imagine that they would be very competitive since the build is similar.

The only reason I took off one star was that I felt that the paint finish was not as nice as my hydro flask.  The paint finish has a very rough matte feel.  It looks very cool but isn't my preference.  I do think that the paint will hold up to abuse and the bottle construction feels nearly bomb proof.

*I received this product at a discount in exchange for my fair and unbiased review.

*Update September 11th
After using this water bottle nearly everyday the last couple of days I have decided to upgrade my rating from 4 to 5 stars.  This product works as well as my Hydroflask and doesn't leak.  Although, the paint finish is different. I can see how some people would prefer Kinzi's more textured and rough paint finish.

reviewText: I would like to mention I would give this product a 3.5 were that an option. I bought these because I feel too restrained in full lifting gloves and figured these would be much more manageable with the bonus of some added wrist support. The packaging is nice and simple and can be used to store your hand grips. This doesn't really affect my rating, but they did/do have an odd smell to them that's not your usual leather glove smell. The hand grips aren't the easiest to put on because they will twist when you try to tighten them, but once on, they are very comfortable. When lifting, I noticed that it is very minimal padding, but that's not an issue for me seeing as anything is a step up from lifting without gloves. I also partially like the feel of bare hands. The wrist wraps add almost zero support which was kind of disappointing, but once again, not the end of the world. May have also been a sizing error on my part. You are also unable to wear a watch or Fitbit while wearing this if you are use to working out with one. I do like these hand grips and recommend them. They do do their job and are comfortable, and I will keep wearing them. As a disclaimer, I did purchase these at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.
summary: I would like to mention I would give this product a 3

summary: They work and the kids will wear them.

You could pay more for a fancier version of this device, but I see no reason to do so. I'm completely satisfied with this product. It's easy to assemble and works perfectly. I recommend watching several different videos on YouTube under the heading "ab wheel." And watch them several times. The movement that works best is easy to do correctly, but clearly understanding what constitutes correct movement requires thinking and experimentation. Done correctly, the movement works the abs more intensely than anything else I have done; unlike other ab exercises, this one is fun. Be careful not to overdo it. Initially, it is difficult to tell how hard you're working your abs, and you may experience soreness in your abs that is more intense than you have previously experienced. If so, don't panic. Just wait patiently until the pain has gone away, even if it takes 10 days or so. Then, use the wheel again, trying not to overdo it. Within a couple of weeks, I could see my abs visibly changing in shape for the better. I may not lose enough weight to have defined abs, but the additional strength in my abs is noticeable during normal activity during the day - just a good, different feeling.

Update in December 2014:

I'm still enthused and thankful I tried this way to strengthen my abs. My abs are now stronger by far than ever before. I find the exercise fun to do. My abs are now strong enough that my triceps seem to be straining while my abs are having no trouble doing 20 reps. This exercise is also good for your triceps, upper lats, and the backs of your shoulders.

The top reviews for this knife ARE NOT PRODUCT REVIEWS. They are seller reviews. Please, know the difference. They received knock off knives because they failed to pay attention to who they were buying it from. Not only that, but only one actually mentions the seller. Still, this is NOT a seller review. Pay attention, and buy directly from Amazon. If you fail to do this, do not review the product you get on the amazon review pages, go to their seller profile and write a review.

For those of you who pay attention and want an actual product review:
The best knife I have ever owned. I have owned tons of gerbers and other knives through the years, mostly given to me by the military. I had a couple auto knives and I just never felt that I could deploy them in time for a stressful and threatening situation. I mostly prefer smaller knives, because I also carry a sidearm daily and the knife is just a secondary line of defense. I was skeptical after buying many cheaper non auto knives if this thing would open easily, and it does. This knife is the thing of a EDC'ers wet dream. I compared it to the para 3 and while I do usually prefer smaller knives, the odd size of the para 3 was actually bigger. The handle on the para 2 is perfect. The grip you get is amazing. I wish my handguns had grip like this thing. I wish all things had grip like this thing. I am so impressed, I will never carry another brand again. All these years I have been missing out. The pictures just do not do this thing justice. You need to hold it. Wrap your fingers around this work of perfection and it won't make it back into the case ever again. I would include pics, but there is no point. The only downside I don't like about this knife is the clip. It sits pretty high in the pocket and that is something I try to hide. Out of sight out of mind. So I bought an aftermarket clip to sit lower in my pocket. I can still deploy it the same way.

The best part about this knife, is that it says made in Colorado, Earth. Spyderco put that it is made on Earth... It's the small things that keep me amused in life...

Overall, I highly recommend this knife.
summary: I waited way too long to buy this.

I really like this rack. No--it's not a finely crafted piece of furniture, but it is built well and sturdy, and flexible enough to place on your wall or by using the included feet, set it out in your practice room, or wherever. I noticed one reviewer stated that the wedges that hold the rack together were insufficient but I disagree. If you soak them in water for a few minutes, then place them into their respective holes and press them in tightly, then take a hammer and something to tap them in like a piece of wood (I used a tapping block for hard wood flooring) and CAREFULLY and gently tap them into place, you will find that they hold very well. After-all, wedges have been used for centuries to hold wooden objects together, and if you do it properly, they do a really good job of it! All-in all I think this rack is much nicer than some reviewers have stated!
summary: This is a very sturdy, nicely built rack!

reviewText:
I agree with many of the comments from other users regarding the software and its feedback. It is pretty much bare and doesn't have a lot to offer. However, I am glad to be able to export my information to Runkeeper automatically. This makes the watch perfect for me.

Running (GPS) - It's great. It picks up a signal fast, gives good and customizable feedback, and isn't bulky. I would, however, like to be able to virtually race against my previous runs. I believe I can only do this with pre-set times and distances thus far.

Running (Accelerometer) - I haven't gotten to try this out yet. I am glad to know that the distance can be calibrated to compensate for error.

Cycling (GPS) - This was great and probably my favorite aspect of the watch. I've had the unit mount setup on my Trek for about 2 weeks but have been running and not cycling. Yesterday I placed my unit into the mount and rode a short route. The GPS was quick and the feedback displayed was better than my current mounted computer.

Cycling (Cadence Sensor) - This I have yet to try as well. I did not buy the TomTom cadence sensor. I went with the Wahoo bluetooth and will update once I can get a few outside and trainer sessions in with it.

Swimming (Accelerometer) - This, as some other users discussed it, was ok. I love being able to swim with the device and it not bother me; however it does tend to miss a lap here and there. I swam in a meter pool, which greatly helped the setup considering the restricted units. I'm impressed, but I really want it to count my laps more accurately without having to put 'race effort' into my turns as to exaggerate them.

Heart Rate Sensor - This is a great sensor with no fit issues. I've performed several 10+ miles runs without chaffing or irritation. The sensor seems to be picking up correct readings. No complaints here as the unit always contacts the sensor easily.

Great product, but please work on that software/website! Also, I would really like a multi-sport mode so I can run my tri's without switching between modes/sessions!
summary: Great product - has room for improvement in software
